A Hideo Kojima Game.    Now that I've put some good 100 hours in this game I can write a proper review of it.  I've been a fan of Metal Gear ever since I can remember. I started with Metal Gear Solid 1 when I was around 4-5 years old, and so far I have played every game of the saga, so I have good knowledge of the game's background story.  Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain sets us 9 years after the events of Ground Zeroes, where the Mother Base we built as Big Boss in MGS: Peace Walker has been bombed to hell with all our staff in it. In this game we control Big Boss again who, along with Miller and Revolver Ocelot, seek revenge on whoever was behind the attack to Mother Base. In my opinion, this game, along with (or after) Metal Gear Solid 3 and Metal Gear Solid 4 is the game with the best story so far, it has some impressive turns of events and it closes nearly every doubt we can have about the first two Metal Gears (back when it wasn't Solid). Although if you're a fan of cinematics and codec calls like me, you're going to miss them in this game, there are no codec calls, they are 'replaced' with conversations recorded on tapes that you can listen whenever you want once you've unlocked them. There are still cinematics but not nearly as many as there could be in any other Metal Gear videogame.  The gameplay is fantastic, it's pretty intuitive, it makes action scenes easier since the camera is located behind you and gets on your shoulder whenever you're going to aim, the camera itself is pretty dinamyc and allows you to look around with no problems. Even though the gameplay is good for action it still has the touch it needs to help us complete every mission with perfect stealth. The game is divided in Main Ops and Side Ops (Just like MGS: Peace Walker) that you can complete and replay once they're available again. You can start these missions from your helicopter, which will get you to their location in no time. It also has an incredible replay value.  The 'Open World' concept was what most scared me about this game, I really thought they would ruin the game's essence making it have an open world, but oh boy, was I wrong. The open world concept is perlecty developed with 3 different instances, we have Afghanistan, Africa and our Mother Base which we can upgrade every now and then.  The sound and graphic quality in this game is better than you could expect, Kojima Productions did a really good job with the Fox Engine, you can see this as soon as you start the first mission, a bath of special effects that will be like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to your eyes. The sound, as usual, is one of the things that you will be noticing the most, as it is an infiltration game you will need to pay attention to every single sound you can hear, from footsteps to a soldier snoring.  The multiplayer is a bit dissapointing, so far (even though it's just a beta) it's just a 5-map multiplayer with little (close to nothing at all) customization, something that we really miss from the previous Metal Gear Online.  Another thing you may want to know is that KONAMI cut off a third episode that was in the making (probably when Kojima got fired from KONAMI and got his name removed from the game), that is something I honestly don't like at all. The game is still a very good game overall, but if you ask me, I wouldn't buy it at full price.

Masterpiece /ˈmɑːstəˌpiːs/ noun 1. an outstanding work, achievement, or performance. 2. the most outstanding piece of work of a creative artist, craftsman, etc.  Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain is a masterpeice.   I've been playing Metal Gear Solid since the first one on PlayStation. I have since played every game after that, including Metal Gear and Metal Gear 2: Solid Snake from the HD collection, and after 30 hours I can say this game surpasses them all. I haven't beaten it yet, but, as someone who's enjoyed the story and mythlogy of this series above the amazing gameplay, because I can't wait to see what happens next with these characters, I've been surprised how distracted I've been with the extra Side Ops, managing my base and recuiting new Diamond Dogs to build my mercenary force as big as it can be. That requires a lot of time getting resources and going off mission to explore and find new soldiers, vehicles, weapons, plants, diamonds, and animals for MY FREAKING ZOO, to Fulton out and send back to base. I should be focusing on finding out what happens in the story of Big Boss, which I would normally be doing, but I'm having just as much fun working on my base, which I can't wait to see go from Diamond Dogs to Outer Heaven given the time this game takes place in.   There's also the online portions of the game, Forward Operating Base and Metal Gear Online. Forward Operating Base has you infiltrating online opponent's bases for resources they have and bringing them back to your base, but they can also defend their base from you, which is part of the exploring, getting more money through Side Ops, and sending your men out to do missions, which is exactly what a mercenary force would do. The gameplay feeds into the story so well, nothing is out of place or there just for the sake of it. Then there's Metal Gear Online which isn't out yet, but has you playing as a soldier that you can level up and fight in multiplayer battles with.   This is Hideo Kojima's masterpiece and it definitely earns that title.  I have yet to play a better video game.  Also: You can listen to Joy Division and The Cure on your iDroid during missions.  It doesn't get better than that.

Summary:  I think this is easily the best stealth game available on steam. It has a lot to love and very little that feels wrong with it. If you're a fan of the MGS series or stealth games in general I'd say it's definitely worth trying out as I found it to be one of the most enjoyable experiences of the last few years. Pros: -Great stealth gameplay -AI is smart and adapts to your style of play to combat you better (ie: Flashlights, helmets, body armor) -Tons of Content - I'm 200+ hours in and still having a blast with the game -Good replayability - tons of missions with differing variety and tasks to complete -Buddy system - Go into battle with your choice of a companion or machine with different abilities and uses -Mother base building - Really puts you in the shoes of a leader of a PF where you recruit, send them on missions and build a large base. -FOBs - Like a mother base but is open to invasion by other players (You can only lose resources mined or stolen online, no singleplayer resources will be stolen.) You're in charge of defending it and the people you choose to support. You can expand it the same way as the motherbase and make for some fun online 1v1s.  Cons: -Ending felt kind of weak and somewhat missing. -FOB Hackers - While not common, they can ruin the fun of having an FOB and make me question how MGO3 will be handled once released on PC

Metal Gear Solid V has a great soundtrack, gameplay and story making it one of the best titles of 2015 and one of the best for it's unique storytelling. Hideo Kojima's directing makes this game even better, using cinematic 3rd and 1st person cameras to direct the viewer's attention in a way that embraces the story, magnifying the emotions off all the characters.  The gameplay is great and is one of the best 3rd person stealth games you can get. Players have to use the environment to their advantage, plotting out routes to get past or just run and gun the enemy but doing so hinders you from getting better soldiers which increase the skills of Mother Base’s 7 sectors: R&D, Intel, Medical, Support, Combat, Base Development and Security Team that each play a role and can change the course of a fight.  The game has 3 main areas, Mother Base, Afghanistan and Africa, for the player to explore and find the many collectables scattered around. They each offer different gameplay styles and all have a unique feel to them with the settlements and their occupants.  For people who have not played any Metal Gear game before and are coming into this blind they can catch up by using the Cassette Tapes that also give the player more story to the main game. But veteran players will be welcomed back into the Metal Gear story with familiar characters with the Hideo Kojima style gameplay.  Overall the game has a ton of things to do and explore with its 50 Main Missions and 157 Side Ops that all feel unique and make the player think as enemies change and get smarter in addition to the system that will give them more armor or gas masks depending on how the player decides to take coarse of action. With hundreds of weapons and upgrades to make along with the new addition of Metal Gear Online 3, a free update that allows for team based Multiplayer with a standalone upgrade system will entice players for hundreds of hours trying to complete.  -Legominds

The game could have been so much more if not for the whole Kojima-Konami squabble. However, in its current state which conceptually is unfinished, it offers enough for a solid 100 hour playthrough (I only have 94 at the time of writing but I'll bump that up to 100 for approximation purposes).   The first chapter is very well done and the missions are very enjoyable. Not to mention that tactical possibilities that is offered to you throughout the game. Motherbase was fun to manage. It wasn't too tedious that it felt like I was playing a full blown simulation game but it wasn't too 'big-picture' either. As a stealth game, the stealth is great. The AI is a bit rough around the edges but its nothing unignorable.   What really fell through for me was chapter 2 where around 80% of the missions are the missions you've already done in chapter one but with added difficulty. Now that part irked me A LOT. I was able to look past it though after I did some research and found that the game's unfinished state is largely due to the Kojima-Konami squabble. Because the game was developed under those circumstances, I was able to look past that one fatal flaw that almost did it for me.  Another thing that I did not like was the lack of areas to explore. On paper, the game areas seem big. However as you do side ops you'll notice that you are simply going back to areas you have visited before. The first time you do missions though, especially main ones, the areas are fantastic and very detailed. The areas were very detailed and unique albeit lacking in number. I suppose I cannot ask for too much. Hence, I will forgive that as well because the quality compensates for the lack in quantity.   A lot of people complain about the side ops being repetitive but I for one like the numbness that goes along with doing it. It puts my brain in a state where I'm not thinking too hard but I am also still thinking. It's a good way to take a break in between adrenaline filled main missions. My only qualm is the lack of unique environments.  Overall, I would say buy the game. Metal Gear is a legendary series and MGSV is a good (not great) member of it.

One of the best games I've played in a long time. There is a lot of content for completionists (maybe a little too much), the story will make you feel a variety of emotions (mostly awe from me), and the gameplay is pretty solid. It's a very good entry into the series.  Now I'm not the best at Metal Gear Solid games, so even I can tell that this game is quite a bit easier than the others, but of course I don't mind that. I think the single difficulty is an improvement more than anything, because I don't have to feel like a chump picking easy mode. It's nice that the game doesn't focus entirely on stealth either. Don't get me wrong, stealth is still very important to this game, but you have the means to go about most missions guns blazing without getting heavily penalized, and I think that having that option is a good thing.  For those who crave the older style of difficulty, halfway through the game you can unlock harder versions of missions, from ones with increased difficulty and removed Reflex time to ones where you have to go in totally naked. Even with those, trying to complete the missions with S ranks and perfect stealth isn't exactly a walk in the park - the improvement lies in the fact that you can complete them at all without perfect or even good stealth.  I will say that the gameplay can get stale with how long the game is, especially if you play too many side-ops. Listen to me when I say - do your missions. It'll progress the story and make things much more interesting. Do side-ops when you need a break but still want to play. or you're hurting for GMP (the currency of the game).  Overall it's a very good game and well worth the full price of admission for old or new fans of the series.

TL;DR:   This game is meant for the people who played the previous Metal Gear Solid series with Kojima’s narrative and director skills in mind though being severely altered due to the game’s structure. It will answer almost all of the questions you had about several of the previous Metal Gear Solid games in terms of Naked Snake, AKA Big Boss’s plot line. There is multiple ways to sneak around NPC’s / Player’s bases that will challenge you and feel satisfying at times. Not to mention the vast amounts of weapons, buddy abilities, and Mother Base Abilities you get as you progress though the game.  However, be aware that micro-transactions alter the game in a way on forcing your hand on getting high leveled weaponry and armor as well as FOB expansions. On top of that, the grinding aspect of the game is collecting GMP (The currency within the game), resources, soldiers, vehicles, plants (I wish I was kidding on this.), and other things.   The Review:   METAL GEAR SOLID V: THE PHANTOM PAIN has a lot of mixed feelings with how I felt the 'Last Metal Gear Solid Game' was going to be. Without ruining any of the game's plot, there is a lot of things within this game that has you questioning a lot of things:     How come the story of the game has been reduced to episodic events rather than the linear, narrative path it was known for?    Why on Earth MB Coins or micro-transactions are within a Metal Gear Game?    Why are the main figure heads within the game is are given more radio dialog rather than cut scenes with in the game?    What happened to all the codec conversations that gave the characters within the game a bit of personality?   The story within this game follows the same narrative style within Portal Ops and Peace Walker. Within doing this, codec scenes that were common within the Metal Gear series is completely gone. You will not open up a separate menu in order to dial into a frequency to call people. Instead, pressing only one button will only give information on what you are currently looking at when aiming at something or where you are located at. That’s it. This along with the short cut scenes that often have you questioning why it was even there to begin with will also confuse you. There are some cut scenes within the game that explain the story but there are others that leaves you to interpretation rather than just telling you what is going on. You never know some of the plot lines within the game as it is still remains a mystery, characters that seem to have a personality within the game suddenly become dull and boring to listen to, and the only way to get the full plot line within the game is by listening cassette tapes that you either get by progressing through the game or finding/achieving within game through certain actions. You will get some enjoyment out of it, but soon to be forgotten in comparison to the other Metal Gear Solid Games.  The system of using 'MB Coins' within a Metal Gear game is something that caused a lot of controversy. It would make sense to have something like micro transactions within a game, but the way it is used is seriously flawed. It is used primarily as a clutch for players who need certain weapons or items developed that seems like a waste of time. In some instances you could be waiting an entire week or more depending on what you are developing. The game does give you MB Coins within certain days, but it is typically a rare thing to get on a daily basis and it’s considered receiving pennies rather than dollars amount of coins. So either you continue playing the game saving up MB coins just encase you wanted to speed up development on the main things you are researching onto or you wait x amount of hours or days. Overall, the MB coins seems like a rather dull mindset of the modern age of gaming where the person who is willing to cash out a lot of money for this game is typically the winner. Though, most players will not even use the special items, weapons, or armor based on the cost of GMP and resources.  Overall, this is a Metal Gear Solid game that seems to leave the player with a lot of unanswered questions that seems to be never explained. It is a new phantom pain to deal with now that the story comes to an end like this. Within the episodes and chapters within the game, one can only hope they would release several more episodes to explain parts of the story as well as new map locations to explore. But given the scandal with Kojima versus Konami, chances of seeing an expansion or DLC is far from being true.

If you're unsure about this game because you're new to the series, get it anyway. I was unsure for that reason and took a chance and am very glad I did.  As a newcomer to the series I didn't really know what to expect but I had heard from a friend that the game was very good, and the tags intrigued me. The prologue wasn't too enjoyable because it was mostly story and not a lot of playing, but once things opened up, this became one of the best games I've ever played. I cannot believe how well-made this game is.  Bugs: I have to keep reminding myself how infrequently I notice problems with this game. It's such a quality release that I forget that it's so abnormal for games to run this well. I've noticed a few bugs, only one of which really put me off but I figured out how to get around, and these bugs are nothing compared to how insanely complex the game is. I noticed the game is only on 1.06, so not too many patches. Incredible.  Performance: Another surprise. I'm by no means an enthusiast. I'd rather run the game really well than turn up the graphics settings, as long as I can run at my native resolution. Just for laughs I tried the game on max settings and was very surprised to see a solid 60 FPS for a very long time. Now that I'm several hours into the game I've noticed the occasional dip to 45, but the game does remarkably well at holding a steady FPS even when it does dip, so that you don't notice for very long. Despite my preference for performance over looks, I still kept it at max settings because of how well it runs. My specs are good but definitely not top of the line:  i5-4670 (4 cores, 3.4 GHz) 8 GB RAM GeForce 770 GTX Samsung 850 EVO 500 GB SSD  And I'm running this game at 1920x1080 at 60 FPS.  Gameplay: Here I probably can't say anything that hasn't been said, but I do want to point out how amazed I am by the complexity of the game, yet how well-designed it all is. The main gripe I have with it is that it doesn't do a very good job of teaching the player the game mechanics, but I don't feel bad for asking my friend for help or googling for help...it doesn't detract from the experience.  I'm also very impressed with the AI. It's not necessarily 'smart' in the traditional sense, but it seems more complicated than most AI. I'm always surprised by how big of a path enemies have. They wander. They don't always follow a predictable path. Then again, they're deaf (but if they weren't I'd never beat a mission). It took me awhile to get used to the AI and how to consistently stealth around, and I found this a lot harder toward the beginning of the game with worse equipment, especially.  The worst thing about the gameplay is I occasionally get very frustrated with a mission. This is pretty subjective so I can't really fault the game for it, but you can easily set yourself up for failure on a mission by picking the wrong loadout.  Other frustrations include how much time I spend waiting. I really don't like how long I wait once a helicopter has picked me up before I get where I'm going. This is in the realm of 30 seconds, but you do it often, and it adds up.  And then, of course, between every mission you see Hideo Kojima's name. It sort of breaks the immersion but mostly because I don't think I've seen credits repeated so often in any other game. For all I know it references the earlier games (again, I haven't played the series) but without knowing anything else, I'm inclined to believe the dude has quite the ego. Not that it's not well-deserved!  Story: I'm 35 hours into this game as of now. I apparently have quite a bit left. As a newcomer to the series I don't really understand the backstory and I'm sure I've missed a lot because of it, but thankfully the characters in the story are going 'huh?' at the same times I am, so I feel good about not understanding, at least.  tl;dr  Pros: - Very few bugs despite being a very complicated game - Great performance on mid-high tier PC - Excellent level / world design - Compelling enemy AI - Packed with unique content. Your dollar goes a long way. - Optional mission replayability  Cons: - Long, repetitive animation sequences (mostly helicopter-related) - Occasional frustration with missions where a certain approach feels unfair (YMMV - Maybe I just suck)

The game is fun and addictive. The story, characters, and dialogue, however, are absolute garbage. Never in all my life have I wanted to rip off my ears with pliars, but this game (and the rest of the MGS series) is so poorly written I couldn't help but contemplate sensory suicide.  Honestly, you should only buy this game for the fun replay value. Using fultons to send manned tanks into the sky is hilarious. Actually, using fultons on anything is hilarious AND rewarding because you get to use everything you attach to the fulton. You also get to customize and command a military base which - let's be honest gentlemen - is an amazing power fantasy fufillment.  Though the gameplay is fun, it can be frustrating at times. With mouse and keyboard I find that every movement Big Boss makes is a commitment. I understand that this is a stealth game - and every movement is supposed to be something premeditated - but considering some missions require that you blow the flesh off of mutant alien zombies with rock armor, I'd like to think that the feel of the game would be more fluid. But aside from Big Boss having issues with something as simple as walking, the game feels fine and works. However, getting caught because you accidentally stood up while trying to crawl over a rock can really get on my nerves.  I should also mention that the game does get repetitive at times. But honestly - what game doesn't get repetitive at some point? The key to making the game not repetitive is to step away from the computer every now and then and get some fresh air. Then, after a hard day's work, come back and fulton the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything while wearing an eye patch and smoking a ♥♥♥♥ing cigar.  PROS: - Great graphics - Fun gameplay - Fultons - Power fantasy fufillment - Fultons  CONS: - Horrible story - Horrible dialogue - Poorly written characters - Could have had more fultons - Controls could have been more reliable  SCORE: Strong 6/10, wait for a sale.

I am a longtime Metal Gear fan who has played nearly every installment in some form or another. I own the Legacy Collection on PS3 as well as Twin Snakes on Gamecube and MGS3:3D on the 3DS. My love for the series largely stems from the story. MGS3 Snake Eater is perhaps my favorite in the series followed closely by Twin Snakes. It was the story in those games that captivated me. Yes I am one of those people who enjoyed the longer exposition and cutscenes.  MGSV has left me a little wanting. Don't get me wrong. I am enjoying my time with MGSV. Where MGSV excels is in its smart game design. Its the gameplay that keeps me coming back. The missions are open ended and dynamic with the ability to approach them as you see fit. You can go silent or loud and never feel penalized for it. While many open world games populate the map with busy work and things to collect; everything in MGSV has a purpose. Collecting fuel, metal, biological material, etc all helps to aid in development of new weapons and items. The soldiers you come across at various outposts become a form of resource themselves and can be extracted using a fulton balloon to expand your forces.   MGSV's buddy system also gives you a number of different options for completing your missions. D-dog gives you greater situational awareness and can even learn how to knife enemies. D-Horse allows for faster travel between points. D-walker can provide some extra firepower and mobility. And of course the controversial Quiet provides recon and overwatch support. Speaking of Quiet; yes the explanation for her attire is rather silly.   If you have never played a Metal Gear game you may feel a bit lost jumping in. However the game offers cassette tapes you can play which give greater context to what's going on. Even without a good grasp of the story the gameplay is the main attraction here. One of the other quibbles I have is that the change in voice actor to Kiefer Sutherland doesn't feel significant enough to justify it. There are very few lines of dialogue actually spoken by Sutherland even when Big Boss is being addressed.  Despite all of the controversy surrounding Konami/Kojima leading up to the game's release; I am pleased to say that MGSV is still a very fine game. Whats more it is one of the best PC ports in recent memory. The game has been well optimized and runs at a solid 60 fps. As the last Kojima helmed Metal Gear (perhaps the last Metal Gear period) MGSV is a bittersweet ending to one of my favorite series.

Cook the chow mein noodles according to package directions, drain well, and set aside. Heat half of the oil (1 tablespoon) in a very large skillet or wok. When is is very hot, but not smoking, add the chicken mixture, and stir fry until the chicken is cooked through. Remove the chicken to a plate, set aside and keep warm. Add the rest of the oil to the skillet, then add the cabbage, bok choy, water chestnuts and garlic; stir fry for a couple of minutes until the vegetables begin to wilt. Add the noodles, and continue to cook until the noodles are hot, and well combined with the vegetables. Add the soy sauce and oyster sauce, toss to combine. Add the chicken, toss to combine. Transfer the chow mein to a serving platter, and top with the chopped green onions. Serve immediately.

A must play for Metal Gear Solid fans. The gameplay has improved in every single way from MGS4. Just to clearify, this game is a prequel. It takes place after the events of Peace Walker and Ground Zeros. The name of the game is development. As Big Boss you're the head of a group of mercenaries known as Diamond Dogs. Your objective is to build up your private army, develop weapons and all sorts of cool tech, expand your motherbase, and acquire resources so you'll have the strength to take revenge on a certain evil organization known as Cipher that effectively ruined Big Boss and his men's lives after the events of MGSV Ground Zeros (You may want to play that game first before you play this one so you'll understand what's going on in the beginning).   Pros: -Open World (Although a lot of locations get reused during missions)  -Dozens of hours worth of open world side ops missions.   -Lots of weapons/items to develop and customize (both lethal and non lethal weapons/items)  -Great characters, voice acting, dialogue ect.  -Great music selection from hit 1980s tracks as well as classic metal gear solid themes such as the Peace Walker theme during the mission sortie menu. (Never actually heard the main theme, 'Nuclear', play in the game)  -The game's difficulty scales along with you as you develop more items and weapons (i.e enemies are equipped with more advanced gear as you develop advanced gear for yourself).   -Lots of fanservice (Jiggle physics, girls in bikinis etc.)  -Amazing graphics. The lighting, character models, environments, special effects are all top knotch. If you're looking for a true next gen game look no further. Runs beautifully at 1080p @60fps on Ultra for someone with a mid-high tier pc.  -Gives the player lots of options on how to tackle a mission i.e kill everyone or use stealth to outsmart and capture your enemies resources and soldiers. This is a stealth game so you are rewarded more for using stealth as apposed to not doing so i.e Higher Rank, more GMP, more heroism etc.   -You have buddies with all sorts of unique abilities to take with you on missions. You don't have to go solo if you don't want to and you don't get penalized for doing missions with a buddy.   Cons -No anti-aliasing options. The game uses FXAA automatically for anti-aliasing and it leaves things outlines slightly pixilated although its a minor issue.   -The game feels unfinished storywise due to the whole drama between Konami and Hideo Kojima. There's two chapters in the game. The first is amazing with great story missions and an epic boss battle at the end. The second has some story but it doesn't seem to go anywhere and ends kind of abruptly.   -Lots of padding to make the game longer i.e repetative side missions and the items you develop take real time to develop. For instance, if you want to develop a certain high tier gun, it takes 2 hours of real world time to develop while the game itself is running. The higher the tier of the weapon, the longer it takes to develop (from instantly to up to 2.5 hours).  -Online play is lacking. It's basically running around other players motherbases stealing their resources/staff. (still waiting for MGS Online to be released on PC next year.)  Overall this is a great game and I'd recommend everyone to play it. The gameplay is amazing but the story could have been so much better if it wasn't for Konami cutting the budget and firing everyone on Kojima's team including Kojima himself 2/3s into the game's development. Don't get me wrong, the story is excellent and makes sense in reference to everything previously established in the MGS storyline but there just isn't enough of it.

A fitting swan song from Kojima in regards to the Metal Gear franchise. One of the best examples of what you can do with an open-world gameplay structure. You can sense Kojima always wanted to make an open-world Metal Gear game but didn't necessarily had the technology or the resources at the time to do it. Peace Walker was the first step in this direction. With the creation of the Fox engine and a bigger budget at his disposal, he was able to fully realize his vision of what an open-world Metal Gear game could be. The result is a sublime gaming experience.  Positives: + Stealth mechanics are one of the best seen in a game. + Brings a lot to the table in terms of an open-world gameplay experience. + The AI is exceptional and surprised me many times. + Superb presentation and polish. + So many number of ways you can approach a mission. The replayability comes when you can go back and do a mission using differen't methods entirely. + Incredible amount tools/weapons/gadgets at your disposal.  + The graphics are phenomenal thanks to the Fox engine.  Negatives:  - Story wasn't as good as the previous Metal Gear games. - Some of the missions can start to get repetitive. This is especially true for the side ops missions. - Second half of the game wasn't as strong and felt incomplete. This is probably due to Kojima being imposed a hard deadline by Konami to wrap it up as they didn't want to fund his game any further. - Not enough variety in the environments.  Despite some faults, TPP is a masterpiece and will be remembered for the intense and memorable gameplay experiences it brought to the open-world genre. It was an awesome journey playing through the game and one I'll never forget, even if the story fell a little bit short. With that said, TPP has to be considered, at least to me, the best tactical stealth game ever made.

Every release of a Metal Gear game is an event. You know it’s going to be an expensive project, made over many years by some of the best talent in the industry, almost guaranteed to be timeless. In most ways Metal Gear Solid V delivers. It’s quite different from the other games in the series, and there are some decisions in the game that left me baffled. But the negatives can’t blot out the parts that are simply amazingly good.  I’ve seen sites praise MGS V as “the best stealth game ever”, which is a statement that sits wrong with me. It makes it sound like this is what every other game in the genre has been trying to do, but was unable to until now. This can set you up with the wrong expectations, as it for example doesn’t provide the same white knuckle thrills the Thief series does, because it just isn’t aiming for the same thing.   MGS V is a stealth action hybrid, where either approach works just fine. The series has been nudging in this direction with each installment, with this one being the most accessible to the widest range of play styles. It has the most complex, and the most finely balanced mechanics of any game of this type. Your range of movement, tools and the AI provide for enormous variation and granularity to how missions can play out. At first it feels overwhelming, as there’s just too much to the game for you to master it within a couple hours. This is perfectly appropriate, as MGS V aims at being a huge 50+ hour game.  Because of the length, the pace of the story is slower than the other Metal Gear games. I loved the opening hour, but after that it takes a while before it gains momentum again. I didn’t mind it, but if you’re in it mostly for the story, the pace will drive you up the wall. In order to have a good time here, you really have to be in it for the whole package.  The biggest problem with the game is that the story is unfinished. When you get to the final stretch of the game, holes start appearing. It’s clear Konami wanted to pull the funding of the project, and they had to cut as much content as they could while still delivering something coherent. There’s videos on youtube from the PS4 collectors edition which featured footage of cut content. It’s stuff that would have fit perfectly into the story as it exists now, and only added to it. It wasn’t cut because of a creative decision, it was a business decision. Unlike most games with regrettable endings, it doesn’t feel like it was poorly thought out, only that it has parts cut out of it.   It’s still a story worth experiencing, even with its flaws. There are many high points in the game, even at the end. There was especially one subplot that resolved itself with such power that it kind of blew my mind. On the other hand there are also parts of the story that live up to the “convoluted” reputation Metal Gear games have. This happens mostly when it’s trying to directly tie events of the game with other entries of the series. I see why it has to do it, but it’s clearly more at ease with itself when it’s telling its own story. Taking a step back having finished it, it’s remarkable how coherent it ends up being, given the size.  I vastly prefer a game like this to anything released by EA or Ubisoft, who show only a fraction of the ambition Hideo Kojima’s team do. This game is so packed with layers of mechanics and systems, and touches on so many themes and ideas, that it feels idiotic trying to boil the game down to “is it good” or “is it bad”. There’s so much more to Metal Gear Solid V than your average AAA game, that it justifies all the articles and videos coming out about it. For every bizarre cutscene with the camera shoved right into Quiet’s boobs, there are moments reminding you Kojima Productions also created PT, a game that played with audience expectations like nothing else. It’s the most amazing blend of the abhorrent and sublime. If you think MGS V looks interesting in any way, it’s absolutely worth playing.

As a new-comer to the Metal Gear Solid franchise I can say this seems like a good point to start, Only knowing the very broad strokes of the games' stories (The difference between each snake, the time line etc) ensured I wasn't lost too much in the story.  However this game lacks what I consider the two most important 'P's in game development. Polish and Passion.  While gorgeous looking alot of the world geometry proves difficult to navigate. Being repeatedly pushed back (while trying to climb a one foot high ledge or rock) with the animation of trying to climb a too steep incline and yet one step to the right, next to the rock or ledge we can climb with ease. Big Boss outright refusing to crawl over a pile of bricks or small half a foot high wall, the box flying off you if you trip down a ledge (sometimes leading to an alert) to then cover you as you land preventing a quick reaction. These would be a few example of the things that most often got me killed whilst fleeing or infiltrating and are as well an example of lack in polish.  The save corrupting bug by bringing Quiet with you on certain missions on launch, (something so basic and severe should have been found in QA testing) the difficulty of controlling D-Walker, the pointlessness of D-horse and D-walker due to how much better D-Dog and Quiet are to bring with you. Most of the story being in cassette tapes rather than cutscenes or 'Codec Calls' no doubt intended to be listened to whilst infiltrating however if you trigger reflex mode whilst listening to a tape the dialogue will be slowed down making it intelegible, and if you trigger an alert needless to say you won't be paying much attention to it, thus missing most of the story. So you end up listening to it in the helicopter all the time staring at nothing.  The beginning of almost EVERY mission by dropping in by helicopter with credits as to who is in the mission including sometimes story spoilers, Pequod deciding to give you a tour of the place if you tell him to land in a high danger area as oposed to his direct method in a low danger area. The game having only one boss fight which is in itself not that climactic and even the ending being underwhelming, although touching.   These are a few examples (without spoilers) as to the lack of passion and polish, it seems and feels as though they lost interest in the game they were making half way through, however the controls are solid, the enemies and mechanics concistant, I haven't encountered any serious problem with the game itself (other than the quirkiness of the box/geometry) the gameplay itself is enjoyable throughout the whole game and lends itself well to some absent minded grinding or side-ops while multi tasking.  The game is overall enjoyable however with all the hype around it I expected something much much better, and I had what I considered low expectations because I assumed I'd be disapointed by not getting references. While it's good to play, apart from the helicopter part which I mean... Come on couldn't I just press A to get out of the loading screen and move right away instead of waiting another two minutes?... Other than that it's pleasant overall and even that didn't bother me much until I had beaten the game as Kazuhira gives you a bit of briefing during that time for actual missions.  This is a good choice if like me you want a game to grab randomly after beating it once and just overall busy your hands with absent minded gameplay while watching something on another monitor or waiting for time to pass. However lower your expectations regarding story as it is very lack luster.

Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain is supposed to be the last game in the Metal Gear Solid series and it wouldn't surprise me if it was, considering what happened between Kojima and Konami. That being said, I think you should buy the game. Here's the cons and pros.  Cons -Lack of story. That's right, there's actually a LACK of story in a Metal Gear game. There were supposed to be 3 chapters in the game. Chapter 1 is complete and fun, chapter 2 on the other hand is only about 25% to 50% complete and chapter 3 is no longer in the game (but there's a cutscene that shows a 30% completed ending of the game or at least of a certain arc). Konami tried to fix it by adding in hardcore missions but that's not fooling anyone.  -Repetitive and too simple. The missions, after the first few, start to get a bit repetitive. Go into this village or building, grab some injured/old/lazy S.O.B and extract/kill them. It's easy for the most part, especially with Infiltration Suits, Active Camos, and a bunch of other fancy toys. (Note that using Active camos will restrict mission completion to A ranks and the highest you can go is S ranks. I avoided using camo/sound upgrades for the most part for more of a challenge.) The missions also feel too short in my opinion, granted I didn't do all the secondary objectives in some of the missions.  Pros -Gameplay. The gameplay is great. I thought it was really fun for the most part, regardless of how short some of the missions felt. The stealth can be difficult if you're not careful with how fast you move and your stances. I have a tendency to sprint everywhere because the maps are big and they drop you stupidly far from your main objective and I sometimes sprint into patrols by accident. (Note that I play most of the time with D-Dog or no buddies at all) You can use buddies like D-Horse or D-Walker or vehicles like Jeeps and Tanks to get around faster.  -Graphics and detail. Fox Engine if amazing. The game looks great and the lighting is pretty good. In the first few areas you go to, the villages are well detailed with pots and jugs on walls and guns proped up on tables and anything else you'd expect to find in Afghanistan buildings in 1984. The amount of detail tends to stay decent through out the game, but it starts to dim down after you go to Africa and a few other places in Afghanistan. Africa's buildings tend to feel a bit more empty. A table here, a military table-bed there, a few boxes, stuff like that. I don't know if that was intentional or not, but I feel like it could have been a bit better.  -Online play. Note that this isn't about Metal Gear Online, this is about F.O.Bs. F.O.Bs (Foward Operating Bases) are secondary bases, seperate from your main motherbase, that be be infiltrated by rival PFs (Private Forces) to steal your staff and resources. You assign people to your Security Staff to guard said F.O.Bs. You can change their gear (Armor, weaponry, etc.) by developing stuff ingame. From what I've seen, they automatically just pick out weapons depending on what you assign them and armor. You can set them to clore range (Shotguns), medium range (Assault Rifles and LMGs), and long range (Sniper rifles). You can also mark important positions you want them to guard on your F.O.Bs decks. Secuirty will prioritze patrolling and watching these areas. You can also develope security cameras, camera/gun UAVs, security claymores, and laser tripwires. Probably the last Metal Gear Solid, MGS V was for me (a die hard MGS-Fan) the most awaited game the last years. And now, after playing through the Story, I'm left with mixed feelings. It feels like this is the best and the worst MGS game at the same time.  First of all, the FOX Engine must be magic. It's ridiculous how easy it is to get 60 FPS with this kind of visuals, even mid-range Systems should achieve that. Sure, there are better looking games, but often you need high-end stuff to run them this smoothly.  Gameplay-wise, this is one of the best MGS titles, giving the player true freedom how they want to infiltrate the enemy base or handle a situation. You can try to avoid enemies at all or you can knock out enemies one by one, paving a way to your mission goal. Of course, you can also whip out the big guns and raise hell (and the alarm), though you should really think about which approach you should choose. While guns blazing is a less time-consuming method, you can't extract and recruit dead soldiers for your Motherbase. The game rewards you for the time-consuming non-lethal approach, as you can expand your army and thus being able to develop more weapons and tools which you can use in the future. The only things I could complain about is the rather empty spaces between the outposts. You feel pretty safe outside enemy territory as there is no threat on the roads, except for the occasional trucks or 2-man-patrols. What could've made the world a lot more organic would be a third-party (which would even make sense, the Soviets are in Afghanistan because of the Mujahideen and not for Snake). A fight between two factions would make things more alive and could even create openings for infiltration.  Regarding the Story; The story however is sadly an unfinished mess. The little bit of story you get is entertaining but that's the problem, only a little bit. If you have seen all trailers, you have already seen most of the story of MGS V. In addition, most of the characters are bland and/or one-dimensional, especially Ocelot, who always was an oddball in the series. He is not the Ocelot we know from the other games. Considering that there is cut content and it it open-world, no wonder the pacing is off. The earlier games were a lot more linear, which helped the story to progress and building tension until the end. The end here is however totally unexpected and random and doesn't really feel like an end, it's more a climax which should lead to the end (and as we know, there was originally a third chapter planned). I'm not saying the story is bad, the twist at the is quite interesting and is still making me think, but there are still questions left unanswered. Overall it is pretty obvious that the story is everything else then finished (unless that was Kojima's goal, as he once quoted 'I always want to betray fans expectations).  If that is really how this epic series will end, then it is a pretty anti-climatic end. Even though I enjoyed this game, there is still this bitter aftertaste and feel that there should be something more but isn't there, a Phantom Pain.

MGSV is a game I'd recommend people to get in a sale, which is something I wasn't expecting to say from a Metal Gear game. The gameplay is great but everything else kinda falls flat.  (detailed review ahead, no spoilers)  The gameplay itself is great, it's the best thing about this game and it's redeeming factor, but the sandbox element doesn't really work to it's advantage. So the game becomes hit and miss. The freedom to inflitrate (or fight) a base from multiple angles works really well, but the exploring and travelling part ends up being dull and lifeless and you'll end up just calling the chopper to travel around. Also you will get really sick of the enemy introductions at the beginning of EVERY mission ruining any element of surprise.  The world itself has no real indication of life at all throughout the map besides birds, solider outposts and the odd travelling truck. There's also pratically zero indoor spaces besides the odd room (usually a building will consist of one room with a lot of reused props)  As example there features both a powerplant and an airport base in the game and it really falls victim to this, I found that places in past games like the Granin Design Bureau in MGS3 feels miles bigger than them due to the indoor spaces.  The story itself isn't gripping at all, If you're expecting a grand revenge story and Big Boss' fall into villiany then this isn't what you'll get.  Plot twists or retcons added for no real reason besides a need for plot twists, characters feel barely present (ocassionally popping in on mandatory cutscenes to say 'HEY REMEMBER I'M HERE!') and interactions are kinda dotted inbetween missions, I had ended up with literally zero motivation to get through it half way through the first chapter. It's worrying when Peacewalker had a more gripping story and gave me more motivation to play through it than MGSV. Also to note: Snake barely says anything about anything at all, besides just ocassionally having a repetition question, things he should have at least some reaction to doesn't get a responce at all from him.   Most of the flaws I feel are connected with the sandbox element, The studio giving up a finely crafted linear approach for a huge sandbox feels like a mistake to me, if it was a more linear experience with open 'arena' areas of infiltration on the major bases, featuring a lot more indoor areas it would have probably succeeded a lot better, as is the opinion I get from Peace Walker & Ground Zeroes. There is also a lot of menu hopping too to do a lot of base orientated things and research, as much as it is disguised as being 'ingame' through the Helicopter & iDroid.  The only blaring problem to me is the lack of Co-op, this game almost seems built to support 2 player sneaking antics.  But the gameplay itself is pretty fun, I'm not going to deny it that. I may have 1001 problems with it but the stealth is pretty much perfect in it and doesn't feel like the AI is cheating you and there's some bonus fun when you unlock gun customisation and things start getting a bit silly. Also the noticably massive cut in the amount of cutscenes is always welcome.   So my thoughts are get it if you really want a good stealth game and/or are an MGS fan, but do wait for it to go on a decent sale first. Fans should expect more of a Sandbox Peace Walker game than anything else.

Kojima has shifted a great deal of exposition into the casette tapes section rather than having his standard absurd dumping of expositiory dialogue whenever a cutscene happens. The gameplay is fantastic, the fact that you are entirely free to do whatever the hell you please makes it for me though. It's a sandbox in the truest sense of the word. You can do whatever the hell you please as long as it gets the objective done.  By creating scenarios that no two players will do exactly the same, Metal Gear Solid 5 literally tore up the rulebook for the series. The Fox engine is absurdedly impressive at allowing this and the cutscenes are ridiculous. I know people didn't like the fact that they got rid of David Hayter but Kiefer Sutherland is immaculate in this. You can't compare the two as actors. I, like I'm sure every other fan of the series will always remember David Hayter's Snake fondly (that sounds really bad. Wow.) but what they've done with the talents of Kiefer is insane. FICTIONAL ENEMIES : Im always about fighting dragons or other nasty fantasy monsters, you got a metal gear as before, and three others nasty villans. Here's the TL;DR review in advance: The journey to the end of a legend is more interesting than the end itself.  It's finally here, folks, KojiPro's last Metal Gear, and presumably the last chapter in the Big Boss saga.  Continuing after the events of MGSV: Ground Zeroes (play it if you can, even if some say it's a demo. It's not.), you play as the 'legendary' mercenary Big Boss in a quest for revenge against those who burned his old PMC outfit into the sea.   Along the way you'll have to rebuild his army using a nifty tool called the Fulton device, which is essentially a balloon (which is then snagged by an aircraft) used to capture enemy soldiers and rescue prisoners, among other things. These can then be incorporated into your army, filling various roles according to their skills.  With this chapter comes a new open sandbox (or 2, actually), presenting to you various ways to complete your mission. The game is also generous with the tools which you may choose, among them including the good old tranquilizer gun, the assault rifle, the sniper rifle etc and also some other non-conventional items e.g a decoy balloon and a cardboard box.  You may also bring buddies into each deployment; at first you'll have a horse which can double as the fastest method to get from point A to B and as a distraction if you use him wisely. Later, you can unlock a dog (or is it a wolf?), a combat mech which can operate autonomously and a certain female sniper with supernatural abilities.  Story missions are presented in episodic order, with credits showing who did what at the start of each. They're nifty at first, but after some time they can be tiresome to look. These credits can potentially spoil the mission for you, especially when 'Guest Starring: Enemy X' shows up, so you might want to look away when they show up.   There's also a new mode called the Forward Operations Base (FOB), where you can invade other players' FOBs and steal their staff and stuff. But this comes with a price though. If you are discovered or if you Fulton away anything, the owner (or his friends supporting him) will be notified and they'll show up, trying their best to shoo you away however they see fit. But the rewards are grand, allowing you to steal some of their best staff and place them in your own private force.  PROS: - freedom of infiltration; be a ghost and stay undetected or go in guns blazing with an attack chopper on your side  - superb gameplay  - high attention to the game's detail. Shot an electric cable? You can actually electrocute people with them. Ordered an enemy to lie face down in a puddle? He'll drown soon enough.  - FOX engine is the best performance-optimized game engine with photo-realistic visuals since GTA V  - silky smooth controls with either KB+M or a gamepad  CONS: - story can be confusing especially if you never played the previous games, which most of them are console-exclusive  - missions can be repetitive after some time. They can be summarized as either 'Eliminate this' or 'Capture that' or 'Rescue that Prisoner', so not much variety there. The ways of how you can do them, however, is the polar opposite.  - development for certain end-game, high ranked items can be very tedious to farm resources for and can take a very long time, even when the timer is in-game. Others can be processed even when you're not playing, but they can take long (up to a week!).  - microtransactions. (Ugh. Seriously Konami?) Comes in the form of MB coins, which allows you to build additional FOBs to place more soldiers in your PF and insta-complete development of items or building structures.  Your mileage may vary: - Plot: A quest for revenge. Let's not get started with the ending. Some important details are also hidden away inside cassette tapes, which you can hear to while you're in the field.  - Music: It feels a bit different compared to those in the previous entries considering the main composer is no longer Harry Gregson-Williams, replaced by Ludvig Forsell. But still good nonetheless.  - Kiefer Sutherland. Some other fans may say he's not as good as David Hayter in voicing Snake, but who knows? Not me.  So that's it, folks, my review of MGSV: TPP. It's one of the most polished games to come out in this decade. Play it!  EDIT 24/12/2015:  Added more substance to the review.  EDIT 4/12/2016: One year later, I'm still playing this, much thanks to Infinite Heaven.  How fun is this game? Fun enough to make me delete my save file twice and play it for the 3rd time through.

UPDATED 2015/09/08  This game starts with an absolutely gripping intro, but the story doesn't really hold much weight. Graphically, it's it's not bad, but not great. Reminds me of Dark Souls graphics (have you seen the facial hair?). Edit 2: It's much prettier than I first observed. Maybe I got stuck too much on the facial hair. This game is pretty, but the environment (Afghanistan) is very bland. Afghanistan is pretty much like that in real life too, but somehow Mad Max managed to make this type of environment really gorgeous where as MGS didn't quite find the mark.  On to the most important factor for me: gameplay  There's something to be said for this game that I can't quite put my finger on. It really is pretty fantastic in terms of gameplay..   I really have been enjoying trying to take the 'perfect stealth' route with no retries on missions. Of course that rarely plays out as planned (maybe I should plan better?). It's pretty exciting to be deep in enemy territory, having managed to sneak my way through multiple guard posts (usually trying to balloon every guard away in the process) to get to my ultimate objective, only to miss one wandering guard and get spotted coming around a corner a bit too fast.   Before long, all hell has broken loose, I'm forced to detonate the C4 I planted on the anti-air radar and the power box (I try to always be super cautious up to this point as a contingiency plan if things go south). From there, I can either attempt to make an escape, shoot my way out, or one of my favorite methods, calling in an artillery strike followed by a helicopter gunship to give me enough breathing room to rush to my objective prisoner/document/etc. and grab it before booking it away from the battle. Even though the heated battle hurts my rating in the end somewhat - it's supremely satisfying.   Other times, things are much more quiet and it's a proper stealth execution.  In short, Metal Gear Solid V can be nearly anything you want that mixes a little bit of Splinter Cell, Just Cause, Assassin's Creed, and Hitman.  Except the story. The story is awful.   Very deserving of a 9/10 in my book. Docked a point only for the general bland feel of the environment and poor story. Highly recommended.

Ok, I admit, the story isn't the best... I also admit that certain aspects (microtransactions...) are less favourable... On the other hand, Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain is a superb game. The graphics, despite not being the greatest man has ever seen, look amazing, the sound is well made and the musical score is simply astonishing.  While some AAA games depend entirely on their story, The Phantom Pain is worth it's price even if you left out the many story missions. The game shines in the open world infiltration missions and base customization. Instead of guiding you from one corridor filled with baddies to another corridor filled with baddies, the game gives you some toys, tells you how to make more and better toys and drops you into the open world with only an objective to head for.  When you then approach an enemy outpost, similarily to games like Far Cry, you can either run in guns blazing, rilling enemies and blowing things up, OR you can carefully mark the enemies from afar, sneak in, using a wide variety of stealth technologies ranging from optical camouflage to cardboard boxes and complete the objective without an enemy ever knowing you were there. It's entirely up to you if you want to shoot, stab and explode as many enemies as you can see, or if you strangle them unconscious brom behind to recruit them for your army. Another thing I noticed was the way the game introduces mechanics like a power generator. Instead of suggesting to look for one, the game only tells you what you can do if you find one, leaving me to wonder what other things I have not yet seen. Another great aspect is the control you get over the protagonist. Where games like Splinter Cell have you enter cover via a button, then show you another cover and let you get there by pressing that button again, The Phantom Pain relies more on the choice of crouching or crawling and the gadgets you get to bring along. A cardboard box can be a spontaneous barrier hiding you from enemies and the optical camouflage renders you practically invisible. If you do want to change cover in a more traditional way, there's a button that lets you leap forward onto the ground or into attacking enemies.  While this sounds like a pretty great game so far, there's even more. You get control over Mother Base, your hub area for inbetween missions that you can upgrade, customize and that will store the people and objects you extract during missions. The game is not so much about it's story than you, the player customizing your base to develop new equipment and using that equipment in the field.  So if you're into third person stealth games, Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain is the best AAA games have gotten in the last couple of years. As a third person shooter, the game still is acceptable though you'll find the real depth in the stealth mechanics.

Many people just like to complain. MGS 4 was a good installment, however people complained of all the cutscenes. MGS 5 is also a good installment, but now people complain about the lack of plot.  As a Metal Gear Solid fan since 1998, this newest release exceeded my expectations considering what I'm used to in the series.   In a nutshell if you're expecting The Witcher 3 in a 1980s military form, you're going to hate this game. If you're a Metal Gear Solid fan and not trying to compare apples to oranges, you just might like this game.

This game is truly a masterpiece.    GAMEPLAY : The game is third-person. You play as one character and use a large variety of weapons, gadgets, and items to infiltrate enemy guard posts and bases in a large overworld. There's also a base-building element for gathering resources that allow you to build new items and gadgets to make life easier.    ATMOSPHERE : The game's presentation is immersive and strong. It's sound effects are crisp and sound amazing. The music is perfect and is almost entirely 80s themed.   STORY : The story will probably be the game's weakest point. For newcomer's to the series, it can be extremely confusing to figure out what's going on, but that applies to most sequels. Even for some fans of the series who only played the numerical games (MGS1, 2, 3, and 4) the game will be confusing because it's story is a continuation of games from outside the main series (Peace Walker, Portable Ops, and Ground Zeroes) only one of which is available on Steam. Sadly, for the most hardcore fans of the series, the story is still kind of weak. The main character not having as many speaking roles in this game as the last games, the lack of cutscenes, and just an odd premise in general make for a weak story. Most of the story is told through cassette tapes that are optional to listen to, but they feel like they take away from the game.   It is worth noting that this game houses some of the most memorable characters that I've seen in video gaming. Big Boss (The main character) is a legendary soldier who has a revenge lust and convulted story. Quiet (Ms. Fan Service) is a completely silent sniper who can hold her own in any situation with the use of her supernatural abilities. Ocelot (Gunslinger Extrordanaire) is a tough leader and intel specialist who is known for his amazing interogation abilities. Skull Face (WHOOOOOOOOOOOOOO?) is a villain with no face, no language, and an amazing story. All of these characters are voice perfectly and I fell in love with all of them. I hated when the game was over because I wanted more from these characters.    REPLAYABILITY : The gameplay spans on for countless hours with tons of replayability and many options for creating challenge runs (No reflex, no kills, no tranqs, no fultons etc). As of this review, I have 110 hours in the game and I'm only at 60% completion of the game. I plan on deleting my save and starting over to do challenge runs after I reach 100%. I didn't even finish the story until about 80 hours in.    MULTIPLAYER : Unfortunately, I can't comment on this much at this point because I haven't played it. There's an invasion mechanic that shows you going into an enemy's base to steal their resources, personell, and even nuclear weapons. You have the option to defend against these invasions and capture/kill invaders. There's plans to release a team-based online game called 'Metal Gear Online' in January that looks promising, but there's not much information on it right now. It's assumed that MGO will be similar to the earlier versions of MGO from MGS4 and MGS3.   All around  8/10  The gameplay itself is amazing. The story while meh does let you fall in love with some amazing characters and hate others as stories should. A good stealth game, but a very poor entry to the Metal Gear franchise. The Phantom Pain feels like a very lazy effort from Kojima in spite of the magnitude of content inside. Its MGS stripped of its charisma and charm, and only shows that Kojima cares more about designing game engines than he does writing compelling titles anymore.  More casual, younger gamers will enjoy it, but die-hard MGS fans will not be satisfied.   On the surface it may seem that the gameplay is top notch, you will get a few hours out of it.. but its hardly an improvement on MGS4. I feel Kojima failed to bring the challenging gameplay of previous games to the open world environment.  The A.I. is not very advanced.. the soldiers' patrol routes feel about as robotic as MGS2, they automatically spot you if you shoot from very far away and there simply isn't much fun to be had with them. When you break it down, the A.I. is about as poorly refined as that seen in Hitman:Absolution. They could have tweaked it in a few areas and given enemies more random/varied responses.  The open world itself is severely lacking in creativity too.. outside a handful of small towns/bases you come across. Various enemy camps have the same copy\pasted elements, so it won't be long before you develop a 'one size fits all' approach to get through the very repetitive second act.. where you essentially have to repeat earlier missions on higher difficulty levels.  You can opt out of this of course - provided you can find something to do for a few hours while your invisible combat units do side missions for you. Oh and theres also usually an hour waiting time when you buy new weapons, develop features of the motherbase and buy new camouflages. The game feels designed to squeeze as many hours out of your time as possible, despite the tedious things it'll ask you to do. It left me wondering why Kojima didn't just cut the missions down.  So my main issue with this game - its lack of story. Kiefer Sutherland is frustratingly underused, the story is simply very predictable and boring.. and the voice acting from the other actors is not strong. Troy Baker's performance as Ocelot is over the top and inconsistent, the voice acting for Kaz Miller is eye rollingly cheesy. So I found the casette tapes almost torturous to listen to after a while.   Once I got past the mindblowingly good graphics, figured out the A.I. and explored the two maps.. the game felt like a soulless spinoff from the main series, so I don't feel it even deserves a numbered title.   Although i'm sure most stealth/action gamers will enjoy it.. There has been a severe lack of progression in the series' gameplay since MGS3. Colour me disappointed and disenfranchised with who used to be my favourite game designer.

I recently completed the first chapter, and let me tell you, this game has my love. I hear that the second chapter feels incomplete, but the first alone was longer than most games, taking me almost 30 hours to complete. The graphics are superb, and run smoothly on my computer. The story(so far) is engaging, and has plenty of twists, turns, and spooks. At one point, I felt myself close to vomiting(although that might have been just the flu) when looking at grotesque bodies. You felt close to tears at the right moments, and through it all, there was a drive pushing me to complete the missions; like it would have been a crime not to. The gameplay however, is where this really shines. Unlike most stealth games, where you have to patiently wait until the guard walks away, or silently crawl past somebody who's back is turned, I found myself thinking through missions, making use of the right gameplay tactics to complete them. At one point, I found myself trapped between two guard patrols. I quickly threw a magazine, distracting one, then crept through where they had just been. At another, I laid down some C4 where I knew a tank would be rolling through. I figured that since there was a truck and another tank behind it, that I'd steal the truck, and drive past the tank. After blasting the first tank, I sneaked over to the truck, only to find my worst nightmares inside its bed. I quickly threw some decoys, activating them in a slow manner, then entered the truck, and quickly drove off. Those are just a few examples of the happy marriage between the gameplay. One of the best games I've played.

Metal Gear Solid V is the best Metal Gear Solid game to date, in regards to gameplay. This iteration has improved all movement, attack and stealth mechanics, as well as using a non-intrusive UI, updating an old clunky franchise to this day and age, with gorgeous graphics and an excellent optimisation for PC.  Missions can be approached in many differents ways, lethal, non lethal or perfect stealth, and objectives can be achieved differently with each playtrough, within its two huge sandbox maps: Africa and Afghanistan. Please note that this isn't a GTA-style sandbox; the world itself is largely empty between outposts and guard posts, save for the local flora and fauna, and it hasn't brought back the live warzone from MGS4 you'd expect in either Afghanistan or Africa. The wilderness is way more like Red Dead Redemption than GTA, giving you a cowboy feel every time Snake rides his white horse, or hunts with his wolfdog.   And that's what a newcomer to the series will like, but longtime MGS fans will realise immediately the plot isn't as polished as it used to be. Storywise, the whole game falls flat for Metal Gear Fans: The lack of extended, gorgeous, cinematic cutscenes, the abscence of larger than life bosses and a major plot thread left unresolved due to unknown reasons (which would be a MGS staple, if this weren't Kojima's last MGS) might leave you with the eponymous phantom pain till the very end of the game.  That being said, the story is there; it requires a lot of inductive reasoning and interpretation, listening to long bioshock-esque audio tapes, paying attention to character motives, backstories and knowing their fate and development in the future (past) games. It seems Kojima deviated from his standard in-your-face approach from his past games to a 'show, not tell' approach, true to his cinematic ambitions, not shoving exposition down your throat, but letting each player draw their own conclusions regarding each character's ambitions and the expected Big Boss descent into 'villany'.   Now, I can love the gameplay, understand the author's narrative choices, but I can't forgive the fact this MGS's soundtrack is lacking original pieces, and spent too much in licensed songs. Even the highly advertised, excellent 'Sins of the Fathers' has an odd, anticlimiatic placement, that leaves you completely baffled asking yourself what the heck where they thinking.   To sum it up, MGSV is a perfect game, but as a Metal Gear game it has noticeable shortcomings in key areas that a MGS fan might not expect.

The solid pacing, memorable characters and Hideo Kojima's unique brand of humor make this one of the best games in recent history. The world is open enough to give completionists plenty to do and focused enough to drive the narrative. Dialogue is sparse in cut scenes but generous in the form of cassette tapes, which you can listen to while playing the game and performing mission tasks. The AI characters each have unique benefits and challenges and change your playstyle significantly when used.   The gameplay is less linear than previous games in the series, with a new focus on weapons and gadget research that will affect how you approach subsequent missions. You are encouraged to be as lethal or non-lethal as you desire, and can attain the highest possible score in either manner. Story missions are replayable if you feel a need to do them again to try out any new equipment and AI companions that you pick up later in the story.   If you have Ground Zeroes and thus get the Sneaking Suit included, I would suggest not using it as its bonus (silent footsteps) will make the game too easy.

THE GOOD: - Over 100 hours of content (around 30-50 to beat the main story) - Great stealth mixed with action gameplay - Nice looking graphics and a smooth 60fps - Well optimised (just like Ground Zeroes) - Tons of weapons/items to develop and customise - Mother Base management can be fun if that's your thing - Capturing outposts and fultoning enemies never gets old - Optional missions tasks and S-ranks to be achieved adds lots of replayability - D-Dog is best buddy - Great 80's soundtrack - I enjoyed the story (although it is also one of the biggest bad points of the game) - Metal Gear Sahelanthropus - I liked the boss battles but they were disappointing compared to other MGS games - Cutscenes were enjoyable to watch  THE BAD: - Even though I found the story interesting, it was horribly paced and kind of ends out of nowhere - Parts of the plot were never given closure and it felt as if there was no real final mission (because it was cut from the final game) - Most of Chapter 2 - Important story information being told through casette tapes feels lazy - Enemies would sometimes act weird/stupid - Open world is nice and all but I prefer linear structured games - Side ops can get very repetitive (even though they never stop being fun to do) - Main missions can also get repetitive (save this dude, extract that guy, etc.)  CONCLUSION: Even though the story is one of the worst in the series, the gameplay more than makes up for it. Besides, it's not like the story was TERRIBLE.  Metal Gear Solid 3 is still my favourite and I'd probably place The Phantom Pain as my second favourite.

Metal Gear Solid 5 is a great close to the Metal Gear series. The updates and graphics make the game feel really smooth. I just wish it would feel a bit more seemless when it came to controls in combat. Occasionally I have issues with the controls not going through correctly. Even in the repeated missions they are changed up slightly so they aren't really repetitive. My other main issue would be that the online feature of invading is a bit buggy, and Metal Gear Online has been really bumpy. Also resources for your base feel like a long grind rather than a side mission. I enjoyed the story, but I could tell that pieces were missing, and I felt that there were just not enough boss battles. All in all I would give Metal Gear Solid 5 a 4/5. The game isn't perfect, but it is a really big improvement overall and I am happy where the series has come. It breaks my heart that Konami will be holding the IP hostage and this will most likely be the last Metal Gear that Kojima will have a hand in.

Gameplay is amazing! The devs really wanted to give you complete freedom in how you control the action. If you wanna go in all sneaky like, you can do that. If not, then you can bust out the LMGs and start spraying and praying. The game gives you hundreds of guns to choose from just so you can do what ever it is you wanna do, kill peeps or don't kill peeps, it's your choice. As an added extra you can call in air support and bombardment strikes on your enemies! How cool is that!? I wasted so much GMP just so I can get the satisfaction of blowing away my enemies. Gameplay is a 10/10. Only issue is that you have to hold down the mouse button to aim, which really blows hard.   Story wise, the game sort of suffers in this department. The story starts out really strong (it has a really good intro, one of the best I've seen) and starts to fall apart at the half way point; this might have been caused by Konamii's problems during 2015. When you get to later missions, around mission 40, the story just 'vanishes' - it felt incomplete. If only konamii didn't have to mess things up, we might have gotten something complete and truly amazing. Overall I give the story a 5/10.   In terms of optimization, this game is truly golden. It runs super smooth at 60fps on my system. I'm rocking a 8350 + 390 and this game is able to get 60fps solid at 4k at high settings! Pretty awesome! Optimization definitely gets a 10/10.  Multiplayer just came out for this game, and it's not what i expected. I tried it out and my god, it is not good. Run and gun is all I saw in the first few matches I've seen. When I pictured MGS online, i pictured stealth and tactics, and slow paced matches. Instead I was treated to bullet fire, and me shooting back. No stealth, just a gun fight. In my first match I literaly spawned in with a guy shooting at me with a minigun from a walker-gear. Then I thought to myself, damn, I thought this was supposed to be all stealthy and shiii. Multiplayer gets a 3/10 for me. Killing people just isn't as satisfying in this game for some odd reason.   Overall, the game is great! If you're looking for a stealth game then get this one. Just take the story for what it is, an incomplete mess due to konamii screwing things up.

Metal Gear Solid V is yet another game about stealth, but this one is different, and in a lot of good ways, the world created is a charming yet surprisingly deep land of politics and interesting characters all around.  Instead of writing an essay about this i'm going to create a list of Positives and Negatives, I know when you're just looking to see if a game is worth playing you usually don't want to read all that much.  Positives  - The story always seems to be moving forwards and never seems to slow down always introducing new and interesting characters to meet. - The art style is beautiful, the world in general is extremely bright and colourful and everything is outline with more of a red tone than most games, this helps to differentiate its style from the crowd and really makes it a pleasure to view. - The characters are all interesting and I always found myself wanting to learn more about them and their origins. - The relationship between Big Boss and Kaz is great.  Negatives - The relationship between Big Boss and Kaz might turn off some players. - The 'stealth mechanic' is interesting in some areas but it does get rid of some of the tension from certain battles. - The game ends on an extreme cliffhanger - Sound was nothing special.   I would recommend Metal Gear Solid V to most people if only because it is extremely short at this stage, it won't take you long to power through the whole game, however if you don't like cliffhangers you should definitely hold off on playing Metal Gear Solid V
