Good things:  - hundreds of weapons and items to develop - customisation options (weapons, vehicles, companions) - the game keeps surprising as the player progress through the campaign, new interesting options get unlocked - very large world - base development   Bad things:  - the game is very poorly ported from console    tutorials show you what console buttons to press to do certain things    items such as night vision cannot be assigned to certain key, they are selectable from a round 8-item menu    mouse pointer in the menus cannot be used to click anything, you have to navigate through the menu with keyboard while left click will click currently selected button regardless of where your mouse pointer is    when selling resources, you cannot just type in a number, you have to hold A/D until to decrease/increase it until you get to the desired amount    game doesn't accept more than 2 buttons being pressed at once, so forget about holding A and W and looking through binoculars (hold F) or switching lights in the car while you are driving and turning  - bugs - not many, but a predicted trajectory of grenade changing the moment you release mouse button makes grenades pretty useless. Also there are multiple bugs in scripting preventing you from doing all tasks (achievement), e.g. guards will get suspicious because they found the bodies... of the prisoners they killed a minute ago... - the beginning of the game is very slow and boring, be prepared for an hour long very bad movie rather than a game - when you complete a campaign, you lose the best companion who will not be available unless you modify game's source code - you are being penalised for non-stealthy lethal playstyle with stupid look of your character

Take on meeeeeeeee~. I've had a mixed relationship with this game. Initially I couldn't stand it. You're put into a giant open-world thats practically empty save for a few copy-paste guardposts and three unique good bases to infilitrate. The main missions take place in said random guardposts where you must kill/capture/stalk a person of importance while exposition is explained via Miller. I got bored quickly and even as a MG fan, I left it alone for a while. After coming back, I started to enjoy the game a bit more. Going back and playing missions in a different way in order to S rank them, I got a better grasp of the stealth. With it the game became much more fun. As of now, I see the stealth as wonderful and the gunplay is great to. Although the story is odd, the main missions gameplay is much more fun then any of the side objectives which will send you out to do about 150 menial tasks(save for a few main story related ones). Although repetitive, the game really shines at the FOB infiltrations where difficulty is increased and punishment for being caught is much more serious then in singleplayer.   I loved PP, but its nowhere near as good as any other Metal Gear Game, even Ground Zeroes felt more like its predesscors than this. But, if you look at it as its own thing instead of a Metal Gear entry, its a good game. The visuals are great, the score is fantastic, and the stealth and gunplay are as good as it gets for a first-person style game. There are three big downsides though. The first being that the game decides to uses these mechanics in order to infilitrate the same bases many times to do repetitive tasks that relates to the story because the pre and post briefing given to you by Miller. The second problem being, although I try to not see it as a Metal Gear game, the bosses are ENTIRELY lack luster. Every MG before it (excluding GZ) has had a good number of wonderful bosses, but PP only has two bosses both of which are plain and boring, and four if you want to count the skulls (and if we are, atleast Metal Archae was a good boss mission). Even if I don't view it as a Metal Gear game, the bosses still only exist JUST to exist and are not fun or interseting in any way.    The final mission and final 'boss' might just be the greatest problem. The last mission involves you saving Quiet. The big final battle is nothing more than +10 armored vehicles which you must kill with rockets. Thats it. This wouldn't even be a problem if the game were kept in its original state where there was going to be a third act, and this would not have been the final mission. The third act, 'Kingdom of the Flies' would have involved a second fight with Sahelanthropus. Even if this fight was the same as the first lack luster fight with Sahelanthropus, it would have been a much more fulfilling ending both gameplay and story wise. At the time I write this, its not really known why Konami decided to cut Kingdom of Flies from the game. There is the possibility of it unlocking after all nuclear warheads are dismantled, but this is most likely the nuclear war secret ending that was leaked months ago. Where Kingdom of the Flies future lies is a mystery.    So overall is this a good game? Ehh it depends. I've definetly put a lot of hours into it and I feel as if its one, but its certainly no good Metal Gear Game. If you enjoy open world games or first person shooters and would like to see some stealth added into, this game is great, so I would reccomend it to most all people. But, if you are going into it and buying it sorely because of the name and story of Metal Gear, I feel as if you will be disappointed.

GAMEPLAY --------------------------  Gameplay 10/10 IMO  I have never seen a Stealth-Action Game that allows me to do so much with the enemy, the environment and everything else. Motherbase is a nice place to build up. Combat Unit (sending on deployments, playing missions with recruits), R&D progress, everything is amazing. I spend around 60 hours in this game before even heavily focusing on the main story. By that time I was in main mission 15, but I did a lot of side content.   I would call it the most fun and at the same time 'plausible' (I don't like to use the word 'realistic' in games, it's just not accurate) military infiltration simulator.  If you are a Metal Gear fan it's more like MGS3, MGS4 and Peace Walker rather than MGS1 and 2 because it is less urban environments. The narrative structure is a lot like Peace Walker. Story is better and longer than Peace Walker in my opinion but more on that later down the line.   If you are a general Stealth fan let's compare it with Splinter Cell. Way more open, a 360° free approach for 90% of the missions considering the area you get for missions, WAY less urban. It has it's enemy strongholds but it's about 95% exterior locations, so expect no SC style (or Big Shell) gameplay locations in that regard. Obviously we also only have a few locations (like Afghanistan) to move in.  Lots of main missions are similar in objective but very different from story-context and the general feel an atmosphere of it. Especially the dynamic weather and night/day cycle add to the variety in missions, as does the big areas in which they can be set and the scenarios involved.   Side missions are a little bit repetitive. Among the best are the 'Important Side-Ops' which are marked yellow and have Story-important elements, as well as the normal 'Prisoner Rescue', 'Unlucky Dog' and 'Extract Highly Skilled Soldier' missons. On the other hand the 'Mine Clearing', 'Rescue Wandering Mother Base Soldier' and 'Destroy Armor Vehicle Unit' Missions are really boring IMO since they are set in remote locations and often just busy-work. Could have done that one better Koj-Prod.  Boss Battles, despite being unique and interesting from my POV, are far less than in previous games. In my personaly opinion the battles are by lenghts better than anything Peace Walker ever brought to the table, considering most of those were based on Tanks and Armored Vehicles and Choppers, which are only 'normal' enemies in MGSV. The battle with a certain Sniper reminded me a lot of the Sniper Wolf battle in MGS1 or the Crying Wolf Battle in MGS4, though more dynamic and with interesting touches in my opinion. Based on how you play it it can also have similarities with the battle with 'The End'. Some of the other battles re-used enemies (the Skulls) in multiple battles but as far as I can tell they are only the same TYPE of enemy not the exact same. They are a little varied as well since one of them for example is very close quarters in the style of the MGS3 boss battles while another one was a far-distance Sniper battle. Depending on who you take on those missions and what weapons the experience can be vastly difference if you ask me. If worst comes to worst you can however always call a supply drop.  Like I said though - Quality over quantitiy here. In Quality on par with most boss battles in the franchise (though maybe MGS3 still has the best ones), mechanically definitely, story-wise partially. As for the Quantity, way less boss battles.  Non the less a game worth at least 60 - 80 hours for one playthrough, especially with different support buddies to vary, different weapons to use, different approaches to take in every mission and so on. But not ONLY because of that, just to make that clear. You will not have to replay the same mission 20 times to get your moneys worth.  Later on the game feeds you with a lot of main missions you did before and sets them in 'extreme' or 'total stealth' requirements. Please note I do not approve of this since it is only there to stretch the game artificially, but also note that you do not HAVE to play those missions to progress in the story, you can also do side missions and do the ORIGINAL non-copied main missions (missions unlock in blocks, at that time later on I described it normally unlocks 2 old missions to replay under new conditions and 1 original new one) to unlock the final mission. Official mission count is 50, but subtracting the missions that are 'repeat old mission under new conditions' it sums up to be around 40 - 42 missions I think.  STORY --------------------  Story depends on who you ask. For fans - split between brilliant and horrible, based on how you take the ending and how much you expect cutscenes and actual long story content. And how much you like audio tapes.  Personally I'd say 8/10.  A Masterpiece. Yet a flawed masterpiece.  Despite it's (in my eyes) brilliant Metal-Gear esque convoluted and complicated (though maybe a little less complex than MGS2 or MGS4) storyline the game falls a little short in Chapter 2 and comes off as brilliant and very enjoyable yet incomplete. As if something is missing. Without going into spoilers there will be a story-arc that seems like a very big thing and will not show up EVER again in the story.  This is due to the fact that apparently (following the latest news) a whole bunch of missions including 'mission 51' which was supposed to end said storyarc were cut from the game. Even more recent news dug up evidence of a third chapter of the game (Chapter 3: Peace) being cut from the game as well or abandoned in the first place.  My bet is on the conflict between Konami and Kojima. Kojima spend 80 million on the production of the game, and seemed to have it almost finished, needing some more final resources (since all assets were there and parts of the missions already existed it is reasonable to believe all that was missing was cutscene material, voices and maybe a part of the new map (yes, a new map, probably not as big as the existing ones though). So only stuff that doesn't cost that much, mostly it would cost more time). Konami probably didn't want to delay the game further and didn't want to spend any additional cents. Their policy towards the gaming industry is something most of you should know by now, they want to draw back from it and go into the mobile gaming and gambling market. They abandoned most big game franchises which are all still in their legal possession and they fired Kojima and his whole executive developer team by the end of the year (contract ends December).  All that remains is to hope the 'missing pieces' are delivered as DLC in a greedy attempt to get some last money out of the game, considering Metal Gear Online is still in development. I don't know. It's a faint hope, and a pessimistic one at that, considering I would have paid 3 times to have the complete experience of Kojimas final masterpiece, and I would very unwillingly pay it, but I would pay it. Unfortunately I'm emotionally so attached to that franchise.  As for the story-flow. The game is pretty slow in the beginning, after the Intro.(listen to the casette tapes, that is important). Think another prob. is the story is stretched over a lot of gamplay which has to be noted.  All in all the game is still a brilliant masterpiece. It remains though nothing but to wonder what kind of a gigantic and amazing work of art this game could have been would Kojima have had the chance to give it the finishing touches. And believe me, knowing Kojima as a dev over the years I am sure he is the type of developer who would not have stopped until the game would have been finished to his satisfaction.   Still I recommend this game.  Mechanically a masterpiece by whichs' standards future generations of Stealth-Action games will be evaluated.  Story-wise and incomplete but overall wonderful story which has the typical touches of a Metal Gear game

Metal Gear Solid meets Farcry.  Has very fun gameplay and controls better than most Metal Gear Games, especially the clunkier early ones, although the engine seems really flawed comparatively. For instance, reflex mode sacrifices the organic nature of the old gameplay, but playing without it pretty well instantly alerts an entire camp to your whole presence if spotted. This creates a weird difference in difficulty with no middle ground.  The companion system is really nice to have but D-Dog and Quiet are incredibly over powered, as D-Dog marks all enemies and objects in a radius, and you can send quiet into a base and have her clear it without even going in yourself. D-Horse is objectively the best as he has no ability save for moving around the map faster. D-Walker is pretty useless as he functionally works off principals of all the other companions, but executes them really awkwardly. To be specific you can use him like D-Horse to travel fast, use him like D-Dog to mark enemies, and use him like quiet to  try  to clear camps without entering, but he'll probably die, because even with max armor he has no health.  Other gameplay items include customization. You can easily customized the soundtrack, your guns, your logo, your base color, your companions, your clothes, your vehicles, and  you.    Also this is going to be hard to explain if you didn't play Peace Walker, so if you played Peace Walker you spend most of the time in the Phantom Pain developing weapons and items, fultoning soldiers, and being Big Boss.   If you didn't play Peace Walker then I'll explain that you play as an ex-CIA agent   that got duped by the U.S. into killing his old mentor  , but like 20 years after all that. So you're essential a legendary soldier that looks like a drunk pirate who is so respected that he can steal a soldier from anywhere, serving any military, and send them to your oil rig base in the middle of nowhere by having them tied to a balloon and pulled there by a plane.   (that's what Kojima thinks the fulton recovery system is)   In fact, they respect and idolize you so much that they forget about their family and friends to live on your oil rig base in the middle of the ocean and they thank you for beating them up on it.  So that's how you recruit soldiers, which you need for specific units around your base.  Story-wise, the first half of the game is REALLY GOOD. In fact, after you   beat Sahelanthropus   stop playing because it all goes down hill from there. Chapter two is an incredible let down and the story has an ending that, for the bigger picture is really great, but as an ending for the game it sucks. I'll link two videos here that explain it better than I ever could, because I don't want to talk about the ending.  Rocco's Video   Jeremy's Video   The only few problem I have with the game are mostly story based. I didn't like how Kiefer Sutherland didn't talk that much. I didn't like how Ocelot barely did anything. I didn't like Miller. I didn't like Huey. I didn't like Eli. I didn't like how they sexualized quiet ALL THE TIME. I didn't like how you have to watch a cutscene every time you flew into a drop zone. I didn't like the credits at the start of every mission, especially when it spoiled boss fights. I didn't like how linear the Afghanistan map was. I didn't like the lack of face-camo I didn't like how Konami fired Kojima.  Other than that the game is great!

Upon completion of the main game:  Graphics: 10/10: Not much to say here, these graphics are some of the best I've personally seen.  Graphical Smoothness: 9.5/10: -0.5:I counted maybe two instances where the game would slow down because of graphics, but they were just cutscenes, minor ones at that.  Gameplay Smoothness: 8.5/10: -1: Many instances Snake would start sliding on random pathetically small inclines, and many times a situation would present itself where Snake should be able to climb/drop down from somewhere, but it refuses to happen. -0.5: Vehicles 'door' areas seem to be very picky, and since the Fulton is defaultly on the same key as the action key, trying to get in a vehicle can be a tad bit difficult.  Story: 7/10: I loved the story for the most part, game did a fantastic job of making me care about the characters, the reason I butcher this score however: -1: Forced plot device with severe consquences, I'm sure people know what I am referring to. -1: If certain rumours are to be believed, the proper ending of the game was cut. -1: The game left me wanting so much more, the ending slapped me in the face with a trout, and I really don't want to wait for another full priced game for the rest of the story.  Audio: 10/10: Its all good, nothing buggy or off with it, enough said.  Music: 11/10: Love the Metal Gear music like always. +1 For managing to provoke a reaction with it too.  Online-FOB: 5/10: On the face of it, the idea seems pretty interesting, but there are a lot of problems with it. -1: Grief potential, cause a inflitration totally involves running around with an anti-material rifle and quick scoping the guards. -1: Managment issues, trying to get your good staff off the FOB into Mother Base so they don't get kidnapped just for being there is a nightmare. -1: Mandatory To Participate in, game won't let you get by a certain point without building one. -1: Almost mandatory to be there during an inflitration cause relying on the AIs to stop someone is a bad idea (Because Reflex mode is a thing too). -1 Flawed deterrance system, you are never truely safe should someone decide they want to grief you.   Thoughts: Overall, a fantastic game, would recommend, I just hope that work keeps getting put into it, and that maybe some updates/DLC will add on more to the story for reasons that I do not want to spoil here, yet I'm sure people who have completed the story know what I am probably referring to.

As many have noted, Metal Gear has never or looked or played this good. This is a masterpiece in the gameplay department with 100+ hours of content easily. However, fans of the traditional Metal Gear formula are going to be disappointed with how the story plays out. The cutscenes that are there generally have great direction, but there are so few of them and so much of the story is told through cassette tapes that you can't help but feel like time/budget constraints may have been a limiting factor here. The same can be said for the ending which, at best, leaves a lot of threads hanging (Kojima still managed to fit in another bait-and-switch in there even if it somewhat obvious). We all expected this game to bridge the story gap between the events of Peace Walker and Metal Gear 1, but unfortunately I don't think it does a great job on that front.   With that said, It's been a long time since I've had this much fun with an open-world game. TPP exists within a bloated genre that's nearly been run into the ground over the years thanks to the likes of Ubisoft and their checklist simulators. This is a game that gives you a lot to do and the appropriate level of context for what you're doing, and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is it so refreshing. I wholeheartedly recommend this to anyone who's even remotely interested in TPP. Provided you can look past the story issues, I think you'll find that this is one of the best stealth-action games ever made.   (Quick note on the PC port: it's well optimized and has a ton of graphical options that you can tweak your liking. I'd recommend playing with a controller however as the menus don't have mouse support for some strange reason. Potentially the most divisive game in the series. My review will focus on the story first (what's always been the meat of the series) and the gameplay last. Both are good, but very different reasons.  The storytelling this time around is focused primarily on cassette tapes... These cassettes are where 80% of the dialogue is. So you won't be seeing a lot of epic cutscenes like in older MGS titles. Are the crazy conspiracies all there? Yes, but what makes this adventure different are paths it decides to take. If you were looking for the MGS title to answer all of your questions, and culminate in Solid Snake taking down Big Boss... you won't find it here. MGSV will leave you with the age old questions, and then some... The character development is pretty good, considering Kojima's source of inspiration for this game. Some necessary reading is the George Orwell novel titled 1984. The entire 2nd chapter of the game is a narrative fever dream... and there are a lot of holes left unfilled. You'll either be fine with this, or absolutely hate it. The most obvious reason most people will jump to is that the game is unfinished, which is true... however Kojima obviously aimed for a theme to the game, and it's a genius theme that a lot of people don't like. Mostly because the plot points, and ending bring you a billion more questions than they do answers. Assuming cut content is not canon, and some of it isn't... we are left to interpret the way things are. Much like MGS2... but quite a bit differently. Obviously Mission 51 was meant to be canon, otherwise they wouldn't have put footage from it on the CE disc for consoles.   Anyways the themes of this game are definitely an echo from MGS2... so if you didn't like the ending of MGS2 at the time, you likely won't enjoy the narrative that this game weaves. However for me, I love the surreality of the entire game. It's a much more ethereal game, made to make you think... instead of hamfisting answers that make no sense, and Deus Ex Machina into everything. I mean that's still there to some extent... but there's a lot of things that leave you guessing.  Gameplay wise this game is pretty different. It contains the mission structure from Peace Walker, however each mission may take you around 30-45 minutes depending on skill, and approach. There are a billion ways to approach ANY main story mission in this game, and that's a feat. You want to lure a bear into an encampment and let the enemy deal with that? Go for it. You want to create a huge explosive distraction, and sneak behind the enemy lines while they're focused on it, yup. You want to sneak in from above, while sniping guard towers to lower their visibility? Yeah. Completely eliminate EVERY soldier from an encampment, sure thing. This game is one of the first few games where I really felt that the whole 'approach any mission the way you want to!' promise is entirely true. I could have gone and hijack a tank to battle the armored vehicle that was approaching, I could have ambushed it with C-4... I could have set up a distraction and snuck up and full toned the whole vehicle along with everyone inside, but instead I blared Final Countdown from my helicopter, while I fought the vehicle on horseback circling behind mountains and periodically firing GROM-I missiles.  For once the concept of 'freedom' is true... and this game is HARD, I've seen many people play it, and they get caught CONSTANTLY, and gunned down. Marking enemies is vital, and sometimes there will be a few that you couldn't see from your vantage point... constantly staying aware of what the enemies are doing, and listening for footsteps, etc.  Anyways I loved this game... it's the best in the series as far as gameplay goes. As far story, well that's another matter entirely and completely up to how you view it. I loved the story, but it's not for everyone.  9/10

I had to delete my original review because it no longer represented my views of the game (TL;DR I mentioned that the act 2 is very bad and that there is a lot of padding in general).  Lets get the basics out of the way. The gameplay is great. Want to go no-lethal, no traces? Go ahead, the AI is pretty good but it does tend to glitch out because I was crouching with a knife pulled on a soldiers throat in broad daylight while his buddy kept running in my direction (there was nothing obscuring the view) and the other guard only spotted us when he got ~10 meters close. This happened only once to me but I have seen it happen a lot on YouTube too, I am mentioning this only because it does not seem to be consistent as you do get spoted from pretty far away most of the time.  EDIT: Actually the AI is terrible, I just assumed it wouldn't be that stupid and never really tested it out, you can be crouched in plain sight in bright daylight and nobody will spot you (spot you as in opening fire) until they get closer than 10 meters.   Now lets say you are starting to get frustrated like I did, sneaking up and executing your perfect plan only to have one of those full body armored ♥♥♥♥s ignoring your hold up and knocking you on your ♥♥♥. At this point I start panicking and the controls not being great don't help either so I just lie on the ground waving my arm as the guard alarms everyone and shotguns me to death. Now missions to tend to get a bit repetitive and when all you do is stealth and things like these happen, well you just want to express some rage. Thats when you restart the mission from your Command Centre or simply call in everything you need while stil on the field (totally viable), select the best protective armor you have, the guns with the best penetration, all your explosives and your tank, now go in that enemy stonghold with your slick gold tank being supported by your golden helicopter playing your jam and unleash the fury (of course you can customize your vehicles how you want, doesn't need to be a golden tank and helicopter for you). Made for some of the best moments in the game.  So yeah overall its a very polished and fun game with little problems like M&K controls and a lot of mundane waiting for crafting items. It also has the PAYDAY2 thing with attachments costing like from ~200.000 to ~500.000 moneys and more, the game treats them as like new weapons but they really are just attachments. Some upgrades are pretty cool though like the stun arm that seems completely useless at start but when upgraded gives you the ability to clear entire outposts by simply charging your arm and releasing lightning on the guards like some ♥♥♥♥ing Raiden straight from MK or Thor himself. Many interesting gadgets and toys like these and you can customize pretty much every aspect of the game from guns to your buddy apearance and vehicles, even Mother Base to some extent. It runs great, and it plays great, more than you can say for a lot of other PC ports these days. If you are not a MGS veteran and if you don't care a lot about the story you will have blast with Phantom Pain. Despite act 2 being pretty much nonexistant being filled with 80% with padding, there will be one mission that will be truly emotional and it requires no previous MGS knowlage. It really was worth it in the end, I never had hesitated so much in a game before, it truly was heartbreaking.  Now for the MGS veterans, its hard to recommend this game without talking about spoilers and why its story isn't as bad as everyone says it is. Also for the fans of MGS series this is more like MGSV: The Audio Book since most of the story and fan service can be found in the cassete tapes to which you can listen any time. This is mostly due to Konami cutting Kojimas funding as we all know. ~~~~~~~~Spoilers bellow~~~~~~~~            So lets talk about the story and the infamous act 2 and some story plot holes. LAST WARNING - MAJOR SPOILERS INCOMING, proceed after finishing the game and if you still feel like the ending was total bs.         You never did play as the legendary Big Boss, or did you? While yes, Venom Snake is his phantom, his double but as Big Boss himself said in the cassete tape he sent to Venom Snake, they both are Big Boss now, their actions and exploits make the legend that is Big Boss.  A lot of people have trouble with the way they just made some random combat medic into Big Boss, claiming that everyone could then just receive the treatment and make MSFs/Diamond Dogs all as capable as Big Boss himself. The problem is also with the weak explenation about how Venom Snake is able to have all the memories of Big Boss. The thing is, the combat medic persona is just an illusion, something to use in the story without completely going nuts and breaking the 4th wall like Deadpool. I mean its pretty obvious that you are the Venom Snake, you create his appearance and give him his name which are actually used in cutscenes. I think what Kojima really wanted with this MGS was not to answer all the questions and fill in the void between Peace Walker and MGS1 but to show that you, the player is the Big Boss, you are the one that made the legend.   Who beat Cobra Unit, Volgin, Shagohod and The Boss in MGS3? Who built a private military force and beat Metal Gear RAXA and Gene in Portable Ops? Who beat Chrysalis, Peace Walker (2x) and Metal Gear ZEKE in Peace Walker? Again, you, the player did it. Why does Big Boss say that you are one of his most trusted lieutenants and that you are one of the best men in MSF? Because he is referring to the player himself, he trust in you the most to carry the title of Big Boss. Why does Venom Snake remembers everything Big Boss does? Because you were there, you played the previous games and you saw it all, you know what happened, thats why you have all of the Big Boss's abilities and skills, thats why it couldn't have been anyone else. Hell, even Miller, Ocelote and Big Boss himself (as Ishmael) say to you, 'Press the crouch button' breaking the 4th wall. And thats why it is also an open world, you are the Big Boss, you complete missions as you please, taking the aproach you want and not neceserily the one that the real Big Boss would find the most efficient.  Also people feel that the Venom Snake reveal ruined the whole quarantine scene. I couldn't disagree more. While it is true that it didn't focus on Big Boss's character development, it really felt powerful because you were the one who recruited those men and women, you were the one who just recently sparred with them on upper deck while having some R&R and now you were the one mercy killing them all while listening to 'a staff member has died'. Yes, I did not explain all the plot holes, and yes the story isn't anything great but I see where Kojima tried to go with it and it doesn't seem so bad anymore or so incomplete, even though there is a whole act missing. I purchased it during the 2015 Christmas sale but never really got around to playing it until now. In the last week or two of playing this I must say it is one of my top games I have ever played, it may be hard to get into but if you do it is well worth it. The game runs very well and looks pretty ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. This isn’t the main selling point of this game nor should it be for any game the main reason I am giving this game a positive review is the amount of things to do in single player a lone. I know there was cut content but even then, there is still more in this games single player than most games have in their single and multiplayer.  This game has a large amount of varied content and a fair amount of depth, some of the side ops feel grindy but are not too grindy where it feels like you have to do them to progress. The game does require you to not just kill everyone in sight as you are going to want to upgrade your equipment once in a while, now although this sounds like a drawback there is something quite enjoyable scanning enemies and then tranquilizing the ones you want to extract before carrying out your plan is somewhat fun opposed to just charging in head on.   The gun play and controls of the game are somewhat hard to get used to but eventually they become very beneficial, something I normally hate in games is 3rd person but in a game like MGS5 this really helps.   When I 1st picked up this game I assumed it would be very stealth based but I have to say going in and just outright killing everyone is an option not one that the game tailors to you early on but the more you get into the game to more it allows you to have fun with dumb gimmicks like D walker.   Another quite amazing thing about the game is the cut scenes, for people who don’t know the Metal Gear Series, it is very cinematic, directed like it is a movie in some cases, this really does succeed as it helps you invest more into the characters and seeing how mother base functions as a unit. I am quite close to beating the main game but I have not completed all the side ops yet or even looked at multiplayer.   I would suggest picking this game up for the price it is at as it is a ♥♥♥♥ing (Metal gear) solid game.  9/10    BOSS?

This is my first foray into the MGS franchise (not counting the Ground Zeroes mini-game that I got for free for preordering this). It's a well done stealth combat game taking place in the shadow of 1980s Cold War battlefields- the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and the civil war in Angola. You play the commander of a powerful mercenary company, and go back and forth between open world maps, conducting missions against the Soviets as well as against South African mercenaries, while also foiling the genocidal plans of a rival mercenary unit.  Pros:  1. It's a well done stealth combat game. You have to use the terrain and various tools to infiltrate enemy bases, outposts, and villages, conducting assassinations, sabotage, kidnappings, and theft. 2. The graphics are absolutely gorgeous (and, on occasion, fairly gory).  3. It has an interesting system of having a 'buddy' who assists you in your missions- a dog, a horse, or a scantily-clad sniper lady. 4. In the late game, it adds new elements to make things more interesting, such as 'subsistance' missions, which involve dropping into a hot zone with nothing but the clothes on your back, and having to conduct a mission (you gather weapons and gear from soldiers you encounter during the mission). Another example is 'Total Stealth' missions that require you to never be spotted by an enemy while completing your mission.  Cons:  1. There's some elements of supernatural-type stuff, such as the zombies seen in trailer that Steam's playing as I type this. It was kind of jarring, and distracted from the otherwise fairly realistic feel of the game. I wasn't a fan. 2. The FOB stuff- you are forced to play this largely un-fun, online battle system. Supposedly you can opt out, but if you do, you are unable to access the top tiers of the research technologies. The missions involve infiltrating the bases of other players, fighting the mercenaries in that player's company. and if you succeed, you steal some of their resources and mercenaries (if that player happens to be online, they can choose to assist their mercs in defending against you). It's frustrating to log into the game and find that your troops and resources were stolen while you were offline. We shouldn't be FORCED to play a game we don't want to play, or be punished if we choose to opt out. 3. Grinding. Yeah, you're gonna have to do it. 4. It does get a little repetitive. especially as you rack up side missions in between main missions. 5. The 'Boaster' skill that enemy troops often have... holy F*** I hate it. You have a tool that can scan people and determine their skills and what they'd be suited to do- but the 'Boaster' skill throws off your readings, and you think you're getting a great soldier only to find out... yeah, he's average- at best. 6. Probably shouldn't be #6, but the plot- yeah, don't expect much from it. Just enjoy the killing.  Ok, so I've given more 'cons' than 'pros', but I really like the game- I've put over 120 hours into it as I write this. As a fan of stealth games, I adore this game, although I find myself avoiding missions that involve the supernatural stuff I mentioned in the first Con, above.

MGS V is a disappointment. Despite its fluid, extremely refined stealth action gameplay it does not live up to expectation built up by fans over the years. If you are expecting an installment in the well-loved tradition of the numbered MGS series 1 to 4, there is a very good chance you will be disappointed.  The story in this game is poorly fleshed out, spread out too thin, and unsatisfying. It feels like a sketch, an idea of a story rather than a fully developed one. It feels strikingly fragmentary and incomplete.  Hideo Kojima's fantastic trailers have created the expectation, the illusion, that this is a very cinematic game, but the opposite is the case. The far and inbetween cutscenes, although beautifully rendered, are almost comical in how cheesy, badly written, and pointless they mostly are. They are cutscenes for the sake of cutscenes.  The characters remain remarkably shallow and static; they are mostly background noise, even Big Boss himself, who rarely even speaks in this game. Beyond the game's great visuals and gameplay gapes a hole of nothing, an absence of the substance we have come to expect from the MGS brand of games.  I cannot give the game a bad review, however, because I did have fun playing it. The super solid, engaging gameplay might justify a good review on its own, as long as you don't mind being let down by the story.  In the end, let's not forget that I'm reviewing a video game here, not a movie or a book which live and die by their plots.  Is this a good video game? Sure, it's great and plenty fun to play. Scouting, sneaking, infiltrating enemy bases is immensely enjoyable in this game, more so than in any other MGS. Is it a good Metal Gear Solid title though? Does it live up to the spirit of the series? Unfortunately not.  If you don't care about the latter, sure, I can recommend this game in good conscience.

Its here everybody! Part 2 of Hideo Kojima's reimagining of The Grim Adventures of Billy and Mandy. Now I am going to do an IN DEPTH review of this game, and may reference part 1, Ground Zeroes. You can see my in depth review of that game as well.  Story: So this picks up where Ground Zeroes left off, after you saved Billy and Mandy from Grim's Guantanamo-style black site. But Grim stuck a bomb in Mandy's.... well.. you know. Anyway. So they're totally dead now. Hoss Delgato and Johnny Bravo were both on the helicopter with em, but they were wounded pretty bad, and went into a coma for a pretty long time.   Fast forward that long amount of time, you find out how Hoss got that sweet utility arm he uses in the show. It lacks the chainsaw attachment, but the rocket punch more than makes up for it. Anyway he gets up and out of the hospital after being attacked by the literal devil and some floating child who can summon a flaming whale. Its pretty weird. After you get out, you go save Johnny Bravo, ride around on a horse, get Courage the now Psycho Killing Machine Dog. Seriously, this dog wields a knife with his mouth and kills people with it. Lastly you gather up an army to go fight Grim and his spooky scary skeleton unit.  Its a pretty good story, until you get to part II. Then its kind of a ♥♥♥♥ show.  Side Missions: If you remember ground Zeroes, the side missions had you go on an anarchistic rampage on a military base, and also save Kojima's self insert. If you enjoyed that, then you wont be disappointed here.  Kojima puts in missions to blow very expensive military equipment such as Tanks and Helicopters, rescuing violent criminals (thats why theyre called prisoner rescue missions right?), kidnap innocent soldiers and OF COURSE, save Kojima's self insert. And when you save him, he actually has higher skill than Hoss himself. Kojima sure is arrogant.   Gameplay:  Pretty much the same as ground zeroes, except with a much bigger map, Hoss' legendary utility arm, and Courage Manson the Insane Murder Cult Leader Dog. You also have the development of technology in this game where you can spend thousands of dollars understanding the secrets of a cardboard box that you can use to fool enemy with.  But lets not forget the best part about this game. I would like to formally recognize this game as the TOP child beating simulator of 2015. You go to Africa, and there are child soldiers. You often have to extract them, and lethal blows are a no no, but this game cares little about HOW FAR YOU GO as long as its not lethal. You could CQC, Sprint Punch, Electrocute, and Rocket Punch small children in this game to neutralize them. There are many more ways, but these are the main ones that give this game the award of 'Best Child Beating Simulator of 2015'. If you remember my previous review on ground zeroes, Hoss had some clear pent up rage against small children (Billy and Mandy). Kick that into overdrive, and thats Hoss' attitude towards children in this game.  Soundtrack:  They got rid of the Nicola and Bart tribute, so you'd think that this game has less anarchistic views.  You're dead wrong. There a song about you being Nuclear and Wild. So if anything it FURTHER idolizes anarchy.   So overall, the story, childbeating and anarchy give this game the solid rating of 8/10.

I am a massive fan of the series ever since the broken and badly translated NES-game. The games haven't always been fun to play - the movement has been clunky and camera was horrible in most of the games, but I could forgive all that for the incredibly cheesy story and cast of massive hams. I love melodrama and Kojima does that good.  Now, in this game, 20% of the plot in, I feel maybe the master storyteller has finally lost his touch. There have not been many moments that touched me at all so far. I can't tell if that is because the story is too crazy or too sane compared to earlier games - I am not good judge of that.  While it may disappoint in story and character department (in my opinion, anyway), it delivers in gameplay improvements. In the earlier games I felt like I was just pretending to be a super commando/spy while running in a pipe - now I can actually feel like I have great many options on how to approach missions and how to improvise an escape when poop is being thrown into spinning fanblades. Hell, with the amazing technology they apparently had in the 80's - smartphones, enemy-tracing binoculars, wormhole devices(???) and Diamond Dogs at my back I feel more than a super soldier, I feel like a god descending on the battlefield.  Yeah, the game can be really easy if you want it to be. I haven't tried it but I guess it would be piece of cake to complete most missions just blasting everyone to pieces and, if the going gets too tough, summon your own toughs in a helicopter to explain to the enemy the definition of overkill. I don't mind that - I like to have the option. I like to have all the possible options. I especially like that I can...  LOOT EVERYTHING.  Yes, YES, that is my biggest reason to loving this game. I am massively obsessed looter, thanks to all the Fallouts and Thiefs and others out there. I love looting. If videogames suddenly went away, I would probably have to start robbing stores, any stores, even if they sold just rocks. I need to loot. And this game lets me do it. I loot diamonds, guns, useful materials, blueprints... I loot the guards!! I loot their cars! I loot massive cargo containers! Not even wild animals are safe, up to the sky they go too, carried by a Balloon of Looting.  If you hate reading: Stupid story and characters but great sandbox gameplay and you can loot everything and everyone.

A beautiful pile of nonsense. You don't get many games that are so steeped in daft camp drama, yet so emminently multi-faceted - and playable. Everything useful that can be said about this game has probably already been said in the short time since its release, but I'll wrap up with these points:   - You dream about it. I think that's a sign of immersion.  - The action is emergent - you really feel like the game reponds to what you do. Even in the most desperate f-up situation, when you're on your back, firing blindly at blurry targets, when in other games you'd be reaching for the reload, you can always seems to find a way out of the mess. It can be hard, but it can also be forgiving.  - Most days I creep around, scoping out enemies, sneaking about, a tranquilizer here, and stab in the neck there. Other days, I take the tank out. If you haven't played it, please don't think it's any 'on rails' sh*t like 'Thief' or 'Call of Duty' - sure - the main story is sequential, but you can p*ss around to your heart's content in the meantime.  - The graphics are suh-weet.  - Miller is Captain Sensible. About Welcome to the world of Metal Gear, where the world history took a very weird twist already in 1950s. MGS5 takes place in 1980s, you play as Big Boss, who awakes from a coma after 9 years.  The game fits surprisingly well into the timeline, it closes the whole storyline and finally creates one, solid line of a story. The story is complete, finally. From Metal Gear Solid 3 to Metal Gear Solid 4. The gameplay is very repetitive. It almost feels like the game caught an Assassins Creed syndrome. But it's not that bad at all. It's still one of the best tactical, stealth action games I have ever played. The story is kinda missing from this one. But that was expected because Kojima was very limited towards the end of the game. Gameplay Gameplay is very good, responsive and feels just right. Both on the keyboard and a controller. I play my game on the keyboard and I'm more than happy with it. MINOR STORY SPOILERS FOLLOW.   “Nine years after the events of MGSV: GROUND ZEROES and the fall of Mother Base, Snake a.k.a. Big Boss, awakens from a nine year coma. The year is 1984. The Cold War serves as the backdrop as nuclear weapons continue to shape a global crisis. Driven by revenge, Snake establishes a new private army and returns to the battlefield in pursuit of the shadow group, XOF.”   You awake in a hospital to Midge Ure’s brilliant cover of David Bowie’s The Man Who Sold the World. You’ve been in a coma for nine years. After overcoming the shock of being out for so long, you look down to see… the area where your left arm once was. Welcome to The Phantom Pain.   This is one of the greatest opening sequences in a video game.   To begin, let me say that I am not a longtime fan of the Metal Gear Solid series. I played through 1-4, PW, and GZ between July and August, so I didn’t watch the series evolve as they were coming out.   That being said, with the rest of the series so fresh in my mind, it’s easy to make a comparison between them and TPP and say this: The Phantom Pain  is not a good Metal Gear game. Is it a good game? Yes. But it by no means feels like a proper Metal Gear.   It suffers from the same problem a lot of games this era suffer from: shallowness. It focuses less on more, rather than more on less, as the previous entries in the series did. It’s an ocean with the depth of a puddle. Metal Gear Solid 1-4 focused on painting beautiful— yet small, worlds, with great, emotional stories. Focused would be my preferred description. Linear? Yes. But by no means is this a bad thing as many would have you believe. Linearity when trying to tell a story in a video game is usually the easiest way to go about weaving a narrative throughout the whole experience.   Because of the choice to go open world, The Phantom Pain couldn’t properly tell a story. Afghanistan and Central Africa are lifeless. The side-missions/side ops are the same cookie-cutter experience every time: save this skilled soldier, eliminate a tank unit, grab a blueprint. Even the main missions began to feel like a grind after a while. The most memorable part of the game’s story was the prologue— a fantastic sequence in which you escape from a hospital. From there, the story goes downhill. The long cutscenes that the series is known for are gone. Many characters are fleshed out via optional cassette tape audio only. Although Sutherland delivered a great performance as Snake, his talent is wasted as he’s mostly is mostly a silent protagonist: a huge contrast from the rest of the series. This game was meant to demonstrate Big Boss’s descent into villainy, but I must have missed that part. On the contrary, Snake seems like a saint: saving child soldiers, dedicating an entire platform of his base to animal conservation, etc. One of the most beautiful sections of the game is a scene in which he pledges to make diamonds from the ashes of his fallen comrades instead of dumping them into the sea. Is this something that a villain would do?   The antagonist, Skull Face, is an interesting character. However, he’s hardly featured and his motives for doing what he did are half-baked ideas that aren’t very convincing.   What disappoints me further is how incomplete the ending feels. There’s no closure at all. Without spoiling anything, they attempted to jam a ton of plot into one mission at the end of Act/Chapter 2 and called it a day. Yes, I know that there was supposed to be a chapter 3 that we didn’t get and may very well not get in the future. It’s unfair to the fans that the swan song for this series (of which I’m a huge fan, MGS 3 is my favorite game of all-time) raises more questions than it answers.   Was it all bad? No. The game is enjoyable— albeit repetitive— to play. I clocked in quite a few hours and am looking forward to the online capabilities. Aside from the grindy-ness, the gameplay is very good. The graphics are incredible, and the optimization is truly one of the best I’ve seen for a PC port in recent times. The voice acting is brilliant for all characters, aside from a few stupid lines (“Such a lust for revenge” comes to mind). The licensed music is a mostly overplayed selection, though they are all good songs, and as always, the original tracks are great. Unfortunately, the polish can’t make up for the shortcomings of Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain.  VERDICT:    The Phantom Pain left Metal Gear Solid veterans with a phantom pain of their own, and although this wasn’t the best entry in the series— far from it, actually— it’s still a decent title. Between this and Ground Zeroes, I’d say the latter is the better part of Metal Gear Solid V— a more true MGS experience. To someone new to Metal Gear, buy this by all means. But I simply can’t recommend TPP to someone who cares about the series beyond this entry.

Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker 2.  I kid, but this does bear some similarity to that title, when it comes to the overall structure of Side Ops and character/equipment development.  Would I recommend this title? Certainly.  I had massive amounts of fun in this game (I played somewhere between 80-100 hours on the PS4 version); I love going into missions with big machine guns and wiping everyone out, I love going into a hot zone with a helicopter and letting all hell break loose, but most of all....I love sneaking around. There are so many weapons and pieces of equipment in the game that you can just do what the ♥♥♥♥ you want. Fly in with Foo Fighters playing. Go nuts. I do wish that there was more to do or see in the open world; something like Mujahideen fighters engaged in warfare with the Soviets. Aside from that, the gameplay is rather rock solid. Oh, I will say that the development timer is pointless.  Just...why?   However, I found it to be one of the weakest stories in a Metal Gear game. The stories have always been kinda convoluted and somewhat silly, but this just took the ♥♥♥♥. The core chunk of the story was...overly sparse and unfocused. A significant some of the main missions could well have been slightly harder Side-Ops. They pushed the narrative forward in no way. The sum of missions that were story were rather unsatisfying. Skull Face was rather underutilised and I didn't get that 'revenge' feel Miller drummed on about - It just wasn't there. This is probably because of the fact that I derived no motivation from Snake. He was pretty soulless in this game.    He didn't care about revenge, so neither did I. The twist ending after the ending that we got was just stupid. It crapped all over the established canon. And was a retcon to fill in a plothole no-one gave a damn about. MGS2 did that meta crap better and actually gave Raiden a god damn personality. I wanted the real conclusion to Metal Gear! REMOVE KIKONGO!!!      The PC port is very (Metal Gear) solid. The menus NEED M/KB support and there could be a few more settings, but overall it's good. I have a mid-high range PC (I play games like BF4 on high 1080p/around 60fps) and this game's specs were hugely inflated. I have the game almost maxed out, and it runs at a consistent 60fps, with very infrequent frame rate drop. Some people are saying their older machines run it fine. It's not the best looking game on the market, but it still looks nice and the Fox Engine is a damn marvel.  All in all, this game will be awesome for newcomers but might be a double-edged sword for die-hard fans. More Metal Gear might be a turn on for some fanboys while the narative might be a turn off for others.

I've spent 182 hours of Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain.  Without revealing too much, I will say that this is one of the best play Metal Gear Solids, no, rather one of the best playing Action games of the generation. This game is oodles of fun, and is stacked with content (people can say many things about this game feeling 'empty', but this is after having spent 70+ hours in the world, more than you can say about other open-world games really) and is generally a really fun sandbox.  The story, something many MGS fans have a deep appreciation for, whether it be ironic or geniune doesn't matter. You don't have to be a previous fan of this series to jump into this one. Are there references, throwbacks and details you won't be able to appreciate? Absolutely. But nonetheless, this game is FUN, and you don't care AT ALL about the plot to have fun with it.  Also, it runs really ♥♥♥♥ing smoothly, very well optimized.  Do I have any comment on Multiplayer (which is coming in January for PC) or FOBs? The former isn't out yet (and it honestly doesn't matter, believe me, this game is worth the price of admission for single-player alone) and the latter can provide some fun for competitive types, but is negligible if I'm being honest.  TL;DR - This game is worth it, even if you're not a fan. This game is worth your money.

A Hideo Kojima Game  Yep, Hideo Kojima made this game. Don't worry, you won't forget it because every single mission, I repeat, EVERY single mission, you will be reminded of the name of the person who created the game...  MGS games are famed to be story rich, beautiful cutscenes, confusing plots(?)...and linear. So how do they make an open world MGS game that's not linear? You don't have to play the missions in sequence, and what I like most is, there are multiple ways/approach to complete a mission. Go full stealth, or head on rambo style? your choice. If you chose stealth, the day/night cycle will come into play as well in how you infiltrate/exfiltrate the hotzone. Aside from the 'main objective', you can always have something to do. Enjoy the scenery of sunset/sunrise while enjoying your cigar, playing as the Boss who micromanage the staff, collecting blueprints, or even try to grab those sexy glamour model posters! I gotta say though, it really does feel like a boss whenever you meet anyone in Motherbase and they salute you 'Boss!'.  Do you have to play every MGS game to enjoy the game? Not really. Without giving out any spoilers, I do recommend you play MGS:GZ before jumping into MGSV. MGSV is easily the best contender for GOTY.

Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain in the ♥♥♥♥  Well, here we go...  It's great! Mostly. Sort of. Maybe.   I'm a little baffled to be honest how so many reviewers felt compelled to label this incoherent drivel a 'masterpiece'. Overall it's tactless, sexist, racist and goes NOWHERE. No thunderous crescendo, no epic boss fight, no resolution at all.  The gameplay? The experience to be had in the wide open world where the game ha syou spend most of your time? Great, varied and rich. Far Cry 2 with toys, to put it crudely. But what toys! So many and even by the games ending there were so many I hadn't taken for a spin. It never stops presenting you with options, limitless freedom to play about in a fun sandbox but one that is thankfully not aimless. You're constantly making decisions to build up Snake's mother base, replacing the one that got blown up in Zeroes. It's all very satisfying in a way that few sandbox experiences manage. Just Cause is another close comparison but it has none of the purpose of MGSV's open world experience.   What really helps too are the intuitive controls (save for the vehicles which are rubbish) and being allowed to improvise, overcoming failures instead of feeling like you really ought to reload a checkpoint. Every single mechanic and idea just meshes together giving you a massive arsenal but one that's never overwhelming. I loved every moment of running around on my horse or calling upon the aid of a trusty sniper, kidnapping soldiers with balloons and blaring 80s music into the faces of my enemies. For the majority of the time playing, Phantom Pain is a pure joy.   But not always. It starts off the bat with an impressive but baffling opening, dropping a hundred questions on your head before sending a Snake awoken from a coma out to Afghanistan on a quest for revengeance. This leads to the natural expectation that you will get answers or explanations to at least a few of the questions and mysteries born here. At least the major ones, right? Nope. Not one. Whilst the MGS games have always been incredibly daft, they've always been structured and paced smartly, excluding those troublesome cutscenes, and build to strong finales.  Not so in the Phantom Pain, where after a loud but disappointing middle act, it simply limps to the finale via several horridly difficult missions and several repeats of older missions for no real reason. 'Chapter Two' it's called, because I assume 'Chapter We're Rushing to Put Something Together, Quick Just Make Them Replay the Same Old ♥♥♥♥' was too long a title.  To rub salt in the wound, all these tiresome replays and frustrating final missions lead to one of the dumbest, most unsatisying endings ever with a reveal that's so pointless and stupid I felt dumber for simply having experienced it. Oh and it's a cliff hanger. In the last MGS game Kojima will ever make. Woo. 'Masterpiece'. Some will say the story 'doesn't matter' but A) That would be fine if the game didn't dedicate so much time to the damned stupidity and B) that's only half the problem. Cause as fun as kidnapping soldiers and running around in a lovely sandbox is, the game just never comes together to form a satisfying whole. It runs out of steam halfway through and never picks up again, leaving us chasing a conclusion that never comes in the hopes of providing some framework to our experiences. It never comes. Perhaps that's what Kojima was trying to tell us with 'The Phantom Pain?'  Although let's not give Kojima too much credit, since he's had enough of that already with his name plastered over every 20 seconds of gameplay. 'Written/Directed by Kojima'...'Starring Kojima'...'Based on melodies once whistled by Kojima.'  I know there's been a falling out with Konami in the background to this game but I don't doubt for a second that has nothing to do with Kojima satisfying his own vanity here. Or his perversions.  A lot of hoo-hah's already been made over the half naked 'character' Quiet (and rightly so!) but I've not got a lot more to add than yes, it's gross. The weirder part though is how it exists in this odd sexless vacuum. Unlike something like The Witcher or Mass Effect which take great pride in its nudity and sex, this game is so devoid of sex, passion or even the faintest whiff of romance, why they bothered to include Quiet at all is baffling. I mean, the mostly likely romantic relationship in the game would be Kaz and Snake, so why introduce Quiet at all when the game still refuses to have our characters do anything but growl over the horrors of war?  So it's pointless as well as tasteless.   And that's not even to mention the racist caricatures or the the tactful inclusion of 'Guest Starring Child Soldiers.'   So at the core, we have an imaginative, rich and deep game that's unparalleled as sandboxes go. The problem is it never becomes anything more, never becomes a journey or experience really worth remembering, unlike the most memorable of recent open world games or hell, obviously, just great games in general.  I began the game with tremendous enthusiasm and laughed and smiled through so much of my time with it but I came away feeling completely hollow. A waste of a great game in the end and somewhere far short of the positivity I've seen heaped upon the game.  I'd happily recommend it to anyone but with the major caveat that it all winds up feeling a bit pointless and cheap. Enjoy the journey whilst it lasts, the destination is not Outer Heaven.

MGSV Review  I've been a fan of the Metal Gear series ever since MGS1, where my cousins and I would take turns playing through the, at the time, ground-breaking stealth action game. This series is known for intense gameplay, massive and memorable boss battles, fourth-wall-breaking, quirky humor, and probably most of all, extremely long story-driven cutscenes. Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Pain delivers on all of these fronts except for the last.   Let me start off by saying that MGSV is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome, in every sense of the phrase. It is so jam-packed full of meaningless little details that could easily be missed, but make the experience just a little better for finding them. The cutscenes are epic and cinematography is so well-done, borrowing from and inspired by classic movie tropes and very tasteful art direction. (This statement is for the cutscenes in and of themselves...as far as actual story content is concerned, I'll get to that later.) This game's pacing and sense of progression is super effective; there is always something that pops up to keep the player engaged and from putting the controller down (yes, its much easier to play with a controller IMHO), whether it be a new set of missions of side ops that appear, a slew of new weapons or items available to develop, revelation- and humor-filled cassette tapes to listen to, new highly skilled soldiers just ready for a-Fultoning, or completely unexpected twists in gameplay mechanics that tie in seamlessly with the story (I'm looking at you, Chapter 2...PRO-TIP: make sure you extract as many soldiers as you can in Chapter 1! You'll be better prepared for the turn of events around the halfway mark).   MGSV is beautiful. It looks fantastic and runs smooth as butter. The character models are hyper-realistic, emanating a subtle glow that only games like GTA5 have been able to pull off. I will say that after a while, the environments get a little stale since these locations are all you're going to see and replay over and over again, but the level design for each base and mission is brilliant and fun to play in no matter how many times you revisit each location.  This game is incredibly addicting, and there is one big reason why: gameplay is king. Holy ♥♥♥♥, this is a fun game to play. Everything about the play mechanics just works. It may seem overwhelming at first, with the sheer amount of information and content at your disposal, or the open-ended nature of base infiltration (the core of MGSV's gameplay), but stick with it and learn from your mistakes and before you know it, you'll be having a blast playing this game. This is the ultimate stealth experience: you can literally choose however you want to take on a mission...do you prefer sneaking past everyone and being a complete ghost without leaving a single trace of your presence, or setting up a clever distraction using a mix of C-4, grenades, and decoys that you set off as you skirt around the other way while the enemy is fixated on the explosion, or would you prefer arming yourself to the teeth with grenade launchers, rockets, machine guns, and full-on battle armor and busting in guns-blazing? I personally prefer skirting around the area, marking all the guards I see, and sniping fools from a distance with the awesome silenced tranquilizer sniper, chuckling at the somewhat-exploitable but incredibly smart and adaptive AIstaying just out of sight as they try to find the reason for all their comrades dropping to the ground in sweet, sweet slumber, only calling for Quiet's help (one of four Buddies you can take on missions, and who also becomes overwhelmingly powerful late in the game) if I desperately need it...I've taken down entire bases this way without a single reinforcement being called in, and it's so satisfying every single time. How you play this game really is up to you.   What is really cool in an industry saturated with death and bloodshed is the fact that MGSV encourages non-lethal playstyles. Sure, there is plenty of gore and killing, but underneath a satirical, self-opposing glorification of violence, the game actually rewards players who do not kill and instead rescue or extract enemies. Plus, there are no-kill and complete stealth bonuses for most missions that put that tantalizing S-Rank within reach.   This game rewards creativity and intelligence...it is ridiculously hard without having a plan, but once you figure out what works and successfully execute a well-thought out infiltration plan after several game overs, the sense of accomplishment you get is unparalleled. The more you progress in the game, naturally, the harder it gets, with soldiers donning riot suits and armor, equipping more powerful weapons (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ snipers...), and fighting alongside tough allies that I won't spoil here. There were some missions where I died a lot, but those frustrations paid off when I fixed my mistakes and applied the techniques I'd learned on my own, successfully completing the missions.  Replayability: I just finished the story (including getting the “secret” ending) after about 70 hours, and I still have a ton of things to do. You can replay any mission (and a handful of side ops) to check off all the mission tasks, try to improve your score, unlock bonuses, or even just to extract stronger soldiers, artillery, resources for Mother Base, and vehicles such as armored tanks. The underlying base-building mechanic and staff management system is surprisingly addicting, with the next upgrade or platform just around the corner. The more soldiers you recruit, the higher your platform levels get, improving the rate at which you earn GMP (in-game currency), upgrading your support helicopter to better handle air-support and exfiltration situations, or revealing enemies, prisoners, or useful items in the field before you get there thanks to a good Intel team.  Multiplayer: I've had a few (unsuccessful) experiences with the FOB system, so I can't really comment on this aspect. Metal Gear Online 3 will be releasing next year on the PC, so hopefully that will be a fun addition to this already great game.  The musical score in this game truly captures the mood, from tense, heart-racing moments of cautious infiltration to epic, sweeping arrival points. Very well-done and perfect for this game.   Let's talk about the story. To be honest, I'm a little disappointed with how the game ended. It feels confused, as if Kojima and the writers didn't exactly know how they wanted to tie up all the loose ends, as it left me scratching my head with more questions than answers. Leading up to this segment, however, I feel that the episodic structure of the narrative is much more pleasing than the hour-long cutscenes of previous entries, with players being able to play the game at their own pace...if you'd rather get a stealth-action fix as opposed to sitting through cutscenes, you can replay missions or do some side ops whenever you feel like it, with no restrictions or “points of no return”. Despite the ending, the story is pretty interesting, one of the most memorable moments of which occurs in the Quarantine Zone around mission 40...this part of the game made me question a lot of things, and it was extremely difficult for me to simply aim and fire, something I had been doing the entire game up to this point.  Character development: taking a more gameplay-focused approach, MGSV doesn't really have much time to devote to character development, but what little there is is gripping enough to keep your interest. Characters like Huey, Kaz, and Quiet all have their moments to shine...and despite being obviously over-sexualized, Quiet has one of the more interesting story arcs. If you've played Peace Walker, she's much like Paz in terms of internal conflict. It's fun finding out why these characters do the things they do.  Overall: 10/10. It's not perfect, and the ending kind of sucks, but it's so much fun!

tl;dr: 9/10 GOTD  Same day patch went out, fixed my issues, game runs great so here's a review. (As of writing I have played for approximately 30 hrs, and left my game running while I slept and did other things resulting 47 hrs on record)  First, the bad. The bad news is that there are some minor glitches including an indoor shading bug that obscures vision, the paint job I wanted on Mother Base was not presented (you only get about ten choices), and there is some occassional weirdness with movement which is the most major concern I have. It's a console port which brings a set of issues, character control and interaction could both use some tighening up, I've lost out on some pretty decent missions because of issues ranging from control lock to control spaz.  The really bad news is that coop is not in it.  The good news is that I'm hypercritical. I haven't really liked, enjoyed, and felt refreshed by a solid blend of writing and gameplay of a game for many years; this game is not just Game of the Decade, so far, this is the best sandbox guerilla experience to date AND the best Metal Gear Solid (although I wouldn't introduce someone to MGS with this game as it doesn't capture the feel of the first or second).  So, it's good, perhaps you would like to know why:  ~ True open world. As close to a 'living world' as we normally see, but perhaps better executed in gameplay terms than similar attempts, nothing revolutionary but well implemented and goes a long way towards keeping the game fresh.  ~ Good sense of immersion, it isn't overdone and it isn't something you glaze at, if you know the story of Big Boss already than you get that feeling of 'this is it, this is what being Big Boss is.' If you don't there is plenty of optional cassete lore to listen to.  ~ Ocelot is well written, they could have easily messed that up, but as it is his almost loving personality fits the psychopathy we see in chronologically latter games.  ~ Gameplay flows fluidly between stealth and action, the gunplay is decent enough, and the difficulty scales to your efforts and failures. If you attempt something difficult it will be difficult, if you fail you will be in a difficult situation, if you play it safe the challenge will be easy to moderate. Time, score, and style encourage you to put the effort in while avoiding failure; although the game is pretty forgiving in general it will punish failure by ramping up the stakes/difficulty at various rates.  ~ Although most serious games manage to come off as fanfiction, come off as clunky, or are just plain long winded this game feels like it was written by someone with both vision and skill who understood both the characters they were working with and the player's role as a protagonist.  ~ Hidden objectives. You're a commando, God damn it, think like one. Look around, analyze the psyche of your enemy, think about how to get the most out of the current mission; you won't be able to get it all in a timely and fun manner, or at all, but if you put in the effort you may be rewarded. Or, if you're a pansy, you could play the mission a second time when all the objectives are revealed post mission.  ~ Customization. Aside from the weapons it isn't the most extensive customization system imaginable, but it meets a status quo far above industry standard, so enjoy being the Big Boss. As for you Konami, enjoy the dust falling on other developers heads, because you are a step above.  ~ Performance is pretty good, even on my worst computer, haven't noticed any freezing or input lag since the patch. That said, it is still a port that was clearly optimized for console, see the cons I've already listed.  EDIT: I can confirm that the game engine is like an alcoholic lover, though.

Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain in the ♥♥♥♥  Well, here we go...  It's great! Mostly. Sort of. Maybe.   I'm a little baffled to be honest how so many reviewers felt compelled to label this incoherent drivel a 'masterpiece'. Overall it's tactless, sexist, racist and goes NOWHERE. No thunderous crescendo, no epic boss fight, no resolution at all.  The gameplay? The experience to be had in the wide open world where the game ha syou spend most of your time? Great, varied and rich. Far Cry 2 with toys, to put it crudely. But what toys! So many and even by the games ending there were so many I hadn't taken for a spin. It never stops presenting you with options, limitless freedom to play about in a fun sandbox but one that is thankfully not aimless. You're constantly making decisions to build up Snake's mother base, replacing the one that got blown up in Zeroes. It's all very satisfying in a way that few sandbox experiences manage. Just Cause is another close comparison but it has none of the purpose of MGSV's open world experience.   What really helps too are the intuitive controls (save for the vehicles which are rubbish) and being allowed to improvise, overcoming failures instead of feeling like you really ought to reload a checkpoint. Every single mechanic and idea just meshes together giving you a massive arsenal but one that's never overwhelming. I loved every moment of running around on my horse or calling upon the aid of a trusty sniper, kidnapping soldiers with balloons and blaring 80s music into the faces of my enemies. For the majority of the time playing, Phantom Pain is a pure joy.   But not always. It starts off the bat with an impressive but baffling opening, dropping a hundred questions on your head before sending a Snake awoken from a coma out to Afghanistan on a quest for revengeance. This leads to the natural expectation that you will get answers or explanations to at least a few of the questions and mysteries born here. At least the major ones, right? Nope. Not one. Whilst the MGS games have always been incredibly daft, they've always been structured and paced smartly, excluding those troublesome cutscenes, and build to strong finales.  Not so in the Phantom Pain, where after a loud but disappointing middle act, it simply limps to the finale via several horridly difficult missions and several repeats of older missions for no real reason. 'Chapter Two' it's called, because I assume 'Chapter We're Rushing to Put Something Together, Quick Just Make Them Replay the Same Old ♥♥♥♥' was too long a title.  To rub salt in the wound, all these tiresome replays and frustrating final missions lead to one of the dumbest, most unsatisying endings ever with a reveal that's so pointless and stupid I felt dumber for simply having experienced it. Oh and it's a cliff hanger. In the last MGS game Kojima will ever make. Woo. 'Masterpiece'. Some will say the story 'doesn't matter' but A) That would be fine if the game didn't dedicate so much time to the damned stupidity and B) that's only half the problem. Cause as fun as kidnapping soldiers and running around in a lovely sandbox is, the game just never comes together to form a satisfying whole. It runs out of steam halfway through and never picks up again, leaving us chasing a conclusion that never comes in the hopes of providing some framework to our experiences. It never comes. Perhaps that's what Kojima was trying to tell us with 'The Phantom Pain?'  Although let's not give Kojima too much credit, since he's had enough of that already with his name plastered over every 20 seconds of gameplay. 'Written/Directed by Kojima'...'Starring Kojima'...'Based on melodies once whistled by Kojima.'  I know there's been a falling out with Konami in the background to this game but I don't doubt for a second that has nothing to do with Kojima satisfying his own vanity here. Or his perversions.  A lot of hoo-hah's already been made over the half naked 'character' Quiet (and rightly so!) but I've not got a lot more to add than yes, it's gross. The weirder part though is how it exists in this odd sexless vacuum. Unlike something like The Witcher or Mass Effect which take great pride in its nudity and sex, this game is so devoid of sex, passion or even the faintest whiff of romance, why they bothered to include Quiet at all is baffling. I mean, the mostly likely romantic relationship in the game would be Kaz and Snake, so why introduce Quiet at all when the game still refuses to have our characters do anything but growl over the horrors of war?  So it's pointless as well as tasteless.   And that's not even to mention the racist caricatures or the the tactful inclusion of 'Guest Starring Child Soldiers.'   So at the core, we have an imaginative, rich and deep game that's unparalleled as sandboxes go. The problem is it never becomes anything more, never becomes a journey or experience really worth remembering, unlike the most memorable of recent open world games or hell, obviously, just great games in general.  I began the game with tremendous enthusiasm and laughed and smiled through so much of my time with it but I came away feeling completely hollow. A waste of a great game in the end and somewhere far short of the positivity I've seen heaped upon the game.  I'd happily recommend it to anyone but with the major caveat that it all winds up feeling a bit pointless and cheap. Enjoy the journey whilst it lasts, the destination is not Outer Heaven.
