This game has a lot of depth into it. When you first start out don't be dissapointed at how little items or equipment you have. The game basically WANTS you to play it slowly.    PROS:  *There are plenty of customization in the game which includes your chopper, base, avatar. *Many guns in the game calls for many types of ways to run missions and side-ops. *A lot of weather conditions which make the game challenging and realistic. *Plenty of material to run through. You will love it if you like stories. Very emotional as well, kind of like reading a book or watching a movie. *I'm actually happy that there aren't any restrictions on the loadout. Even if you have loadout not suited for the mission you can still call in a supply drop or a weapon change. *You can carry SOO MANY WEAPONS!!! Like literally, you can have 2 primary and another choice of a secondary   bionic arm????!!! . So literally you can have as many different types of weapons on a mission as you like. *Same thing with buddies as well! You can change buddies in between missions so lets say at first if you had   Quiet   and you wanted another buddy to move to a certain point faster you can call in D-Horse.  CONS:*You don't get to know all of the mission unlockables in the first go. They only tell you the important facts about what you need to get accomplished and basically leave the rest blank. You will only know what the 'hidden' side stuff are in the mission when you complete it.   *Mission 22 is kind of bad because you cannot redo that mission if you fail it. If you don't have a heads up before you recieve the mission and die while trying to finish it you will NOT BE ABLE to redo it!!! The downside is you will lose some assets that were signed to motherbase with the chance of getting stuff deranked.  You will be able to redo it if you abort mission 21 and then retake the mission from the mission list before doing mission 21.    *Wish some missions were clearer on what to do and where to go while having better map markers.  *If it's your first time playing a mission you have a choice of either manning it up and killing everything first to see what to do after reloading from checkpoint or you can crawl your way around everything and hope you don't get spotted because the AIs are SUPER SMART!!!! You get detected by 1 person and it's basically missions failed.  *If you don't have a 'decent' computer you won't feel the 'SUPER GOOD QUALITY OF THE VIEW!!!!'  *All drop requests cost GMP which is kind of hard to manage when you want to have all the upgrades available. Your crew will also start to leave the base if your GMP is in the red.  Broke with debt to employees like most companies nowadays    All in all it's a very nice game that will require you to put in a lot of time and effort to play. Don't expect to get A TON of % with 30 hours of gameplay   Unless you go for online guides which are relatively easy to find

'I give my life Not for honor...' ...but because I can't stop playing.  This game will make you twelve years old again. Just watch -- you'll play until you forget what your objective was, and when you notice this, it won't matter anyway. Sneak up on everyone, everything, everywhere, with any tactic, in any weather, with anybody, for any reason.  This is what MGS was meant to be. The sheer variety of well-designed areas, cool buddies and setpiece battles make it a very long and exciting game. The extensive military and base-management elements are more than icing on the cake; you'll find yourself pausing in a bush, ten meters away from an enemy, and using your iDroid to unlock and upgrade or send soldiers on a mission. Not every fan is happy with the story, but whether or not you like it -- it will make you 'feel'. All the tension (enemies are a credible threat, especially in large teams -- yes, they coordinate) and attachment to your buddies and base (you'll love at least one of your mission partners) make it certain that The Phantom Pain will leave you with a longing ache when the battles are done and the wounds have healed.  (Update) MGO3 is here! For MGO2 fans: the three classes definitely make for a different competitive style, but TSNE (now called 'Cloak and Dagger') feels much the same as it always did. And for the first time, stealth play is rewarded with the inclusion of fultons -- you can earn extra points and help the team by restoring tickets in Bounty Hunter. Sneak up on the best players and turn the tides of war! The knife is apparently going to return in a future patch. Unfortunately, headshots are no longer instant kills, but this change was necessary to make the different HP of each class important. You also no longer need to buy weapons and components in-match; loadouts are added. The SOP system is gone, but there are skills with similar functions in the game. I've really been enjoying MGO3 so far.

tl;dr  It's amazing. My only gripe is that I cannot play with my buddies online yet. Can't wait for multiplayer!   Where should I begin? Ahh, I'll begin with the context. Well, I have not played any other MGS games aside from about half or so of MGS 2 (although I do plan on playing the rest asap... just can't seem to find them time) so my perspective on MGS V is not one of amazing expectations, it is one of a newbie to the series who does not know what to expect. And I have to say... This game is fantastic. From the sounds of the few negative reviews with high ratings it seems the expectations for this game were insainly high... and it didn't meet all of them. The story is done in a different fashion compared to other MGS games, but I honestly didn't mind. The 20m cutscenes I found in MGS 2 were interesting, but they overstayed their welcome (at least for me) and being able to progress the story at my own pace is a great thing.    The highest rated Steam Reviews are all negative because people seem dissapointed in the product. I feel that this does not do the game justice, as it is a fantastic game on its own. Now, maybe it's not as good as MSG3, but it's still fantastic. Yes, it could be better. Yes, the microtransactions are annoying. BUT, the game is still fantastic. It might not have lived up to the hype, but I promise you that doesn't mean it's a bad game.   To go off topic here...  This game is the exact example of why Valve is smart NOT to release Half Life 3.  No matter how good it is, people will just be dissapointed that it wasn't the perfect game they all wanted. Nothing is ever perfect.   Update: The Multiplayer was... Disapointing. I didn't think it added much to the game and it was similar to CoD in my eyes. Single player is more than worth the price of admision (Especially at $40), but don't expect much from the multiplayer.

Spoiler Free  Gameplay- It's f*cking fun, stealth mechanics are nothing new but work well and feel rewarding. Not repetitive due to locations changing placements and so on, feel like every so often I go into a place I've been to before and notice change. There's a pretty good upgrade list as well but guns do feel a bit lame, more like shooting a bb gun. There are however a couple of missions which are absolute wank, e.g.- throwing waves of tanks and mech at you for not much reason when you could just sneak away. Shooting works well enough but bullet spray is jacked up for you, enemies seem to shoot a closer group, so make the first shot count/dont get seen.  Also you get to rescue and Fulton extract Hideo Kojima.   Graphics- Graphics are nice to look at, not groundbreaking but 10/10 mlg optimisation makes it so much nicer, it just feels like it works properly. Not to say there aren't bugs there are a couple but mostly funny, non major things. Only ui problem is that it's all console commands. The auto settings work very well, I turned up anti-aliasing and that was it. There's a slight drop in fps when stuff gets absolutely crazy but nothing like jumping onto a ship in AC: Black Flag and having to fight at 7fps.  Sound- Pretty good, environmental stuff is nice, funky bullet sounds, animals sound a bit weird and so does revolver but I think that's just him. Only gripe is I can't hear what the f*ck people are saying, I had to put subtitles on because there's no option to tweak levels (might be in .ini files). Also revolver and miller sound the same over the radio, listening to them argue is like listening to a crack addict with multiple personality disorder have a bit of an episode. Tapes can be picked up and if you buy speakers for the chopper you can blast Aha- Take on Me while rocketing an Afghan checkpoint to bits. Also you can tell it's translated due to some sections sounding well too overdramatic and the presence of 'memes'.   Story- I'm not good enough to play the older ones, fully just rage quit the first level of MGS3, but all story components are online and some are also explained in game. There's some pretty deep moments but I didn't actually even know it ended, I was expecting some kind of tragedy grand finale but no it just kinda stopped. There is a much deeper story through tapes you listen to which are interesting but what happened to MGS4's hour and a half cutscenes? I was kinda expecting something more cinematic. Sitting and listening to a 10 minute tape of Zero talking isn't that fun despite his 'British' accent.   Character developement doesn't really happen in terms of the overiding story, don't want to spoil it but people don't go down the paths they should do in terms of the story, or if they do it's not shown well at all. Especially in terms of moral descisions, it leaves a lot of unanswered questions, I only hope they add on more missions later.   Saying that I did care for what was actually going on in the story which doesn't happen too often. Characters are all interesting especially Quiet <3 (I'm not a weeb I just have a crush on Stefanie Joosten the model that plays her). Annoying thing is later on trying to progress onto the next mission requires you to either listen to story tapes or do two side missions, I just feel it's a bit long winded and breaks the story up a bit unneccesarily. Also some missions feel really out of place and force combat which can be a bit daunting having spent hours throwing people in dumpsters and getting trick longshots with the zzz pistol.   Overall I'd say it's worth the money for the gameplay and fun factor but just dont expect a story like the other games.

A HIDEO KOJIMA GAME! 7/10. It's Metal Gear Solid. Do I really need to review it? Well, now I feel like I do. This really isn't a Metal Gear Solid game. I do recommend the game because visually it's stunning. PC optimization is fantastic, and if you like stealth games it's always great. However, this MGS feels rushed and in no way like an actual MGS title. Your cutscenes? Pretty much gone. Codec calls? Replaced by tapes, which for someone that has access to all the things Big Boss has is a little weird.   My main problem with the game is that it's for the most part just washed rinsed and repeated. Follow this person. Save this person. Extract this person. And.....well.......not much else. This feels like the entire development team stopped caring after Konami and Kojima had their falling out. I don't exactly know what more to say except if you're like me and need the rest of the story give it a play, but if you don't know anything about MGS wait for a sale.  It also feels like Konami just cut Kojima's budget and time and just pushed a game out that needed more time to make. I'm unfortunately switching my recommendation.   TL;DR: This game is fantastic, but not worth 59.99 for a person who has real time invested in the saga.

This is only for the single player portion. Call me what you will, but to me MGS has always been a Singleplayer story game.   This is an awesome game to play even if you dont like MGS. The open world play is really fun and makes me think of the original Mercenaries. A little ways into the game you gain the ability to call in weapon drops and airstrikes which let you bail yourself out of a corner or change play styles on the fly to adapt to a new threat. The buddy system really doesn't shine until you get the all famous Quiet. I can't tell you how much time I've wasted practicing assaulting random fortified enemy positions at night under her sniper cover. Once you understand how to utilize her effectively you can really use good team tactics to overwhelm superior enemies with surprise and violence of action.   The game really lets you develop your own play style with a huge variety of customizable weapons as well. Combined with Quiet, you can tag team snipe your enemies, 'think playstation' and blow up sh## with impunity, sneak through a base and kidnap all its defenders, plus more. The fulton system is a little silly but after getting over that it becomes an awesomly fun mechanic of the game.  This MGS does make some effort to get you to use non-lethal as the other MGS titles do but you aren't directly penalized if you don't. The different outfits also play into the game incredibly well and can make the difference in a heavy situation.  Overalll, it is one of the more 'realistic' feeling shooter games where you have to actually think before you act and bullets really kill both you and your enemies. The story is interesting but can be set aside to enjoy some good old fashoned trigger time. The graphics are great and help with immersion. My only complaint is the lack of civilians.   Back to assaulting enemy bases while quiet and I are both covered in blood.  'Peace'

Still, the FOB matches do provide some moderate fun for a while.  Though, If you want some more challenging sneaking experience, Ground Zeroes is better than The Phantom Pain. I'm a big fan of the Metal gear games. There's something about them that's very unique. It's hard to find a solid stealth action game these days but MGS has always set the standard and this one is no different. It's fluid to control and while difficult to master there's something amazing about pulling off an S rank on a mission with no detections.  It's fun. Hands down it's just plain fun.  Now I'll admit the first half of the game is WAY MORE SOLID than the latter half. This game really isn't 'finished' but look at my play time and see if I got my money's worth. The 2nd half has a lot of repeat missions with quirks such as no detections allowed or procure all items on site. They're fun but they're just there to add more meat to the 2nd half.   The story is engaging and well written. You don't *need* backstory but it makes the game that much more thrilling when you're already invested in the characters. The ending is, like the 2nd half of the game, rushed and I understand why people complain about it. I personally really enjoyed it and I can't really find myself complaining. It's clear that Kojima had a grand view for this game and Konami just didn't want to give him another few years to finish it.   If you like stealth games or just well written, fun, engaging, unique and superb action you will probably like this game. It has all sorts of nooks and crannies to explore and play with. It's silly yet very serious. It's unfinished but left me more satisfied than most other games in recent memory. I really love these games.  If you're on the fence maybe try it out at a friend's house before you dive in but if you're willing to drop $30 on a sale for something you don't see every day I would highly recommend it.

Metal Gear Solid 5 is an excellent game, but it's a terrible Metal Gear game. The gameplay is amazing; it is one of the best stealth games I have ever played. However, the story is where it falters; there really isn't all that much story, and what little there is feels very unfinished and adds nothing to the existing Metal Gear lore. It seems like the game was intended to provide backstory on characters such as Liquid Snake and Psycho Mantis, but it ends up making more loose ends than it started with. The only character it successfully gives a backstory on is Venom Snake, but he nothing more than a boss from the first Metal Gear game, which has been all but forgotten. All in all, if you are expecting another masterpiece from the Metal Gear you will be very disappointed, but it is still an excellent stealth game.   TL;DR not a good Metal Gear game, but still has great gameplay

I cannot recommend this game highly enough, it is pure fun and if the description sounds the slightest bit interesting to you, then you probably won't regret buying this game.  To give a thorough review I'd have to use several pages, so I'll stick to the important parts:  -ABSOLUTELY MOST IMPORTANT: Hideo Kojima is a monster and will toy with your emotions like you're his little Barbie doll in the world of 'W-T-F????' BUT ONLY IN CHAPTER 2. Don't be like 40% of the players on Steam who finished Chapter 1 (mission 31) and then gave up once missions started repeating. YOU DON'T HAVE TO PLAY THE REPEAT MISSIONS TO FINISH THE STORY, PLAY THE NEW MISSIONS AND DO THE STORY SIDE-OPS. There are FOUR endings for FOUR characters beyond the end of Chapter 1, and each of these were like a punch in the gut to me. Anybody who reviews the game without having seen ALL FOUR of the real endings has missed out on the most memorable parts of the game.  -The controls are complex and take some getting used to. Even after you're used to them you'll still mess things up frequently because the game engine is awful in certain particular situations  -The above point is irrelevant because the combat in MGSV is so interesting and fun that you'll forget you were discovered due to a buggy engine and not because you actually made a mistake... It's almost like a reward for encountering a bug. There are many weapons, many tools, and many ways to make your way through an enemy outpost; even after being discovered you can still ditch the enemies on your trail and go back to using stealth (with the base now on alert).  -MGSV is sort of three-games-in-one. You have the story, you have Metal Gear Online (deathmatch/multiplayer), and you have a base-building game where you collect soldiers, vehicles, equipment, and resources to power up your base. Chances are that you'll like at least one of these because of how different they are.  -So important I need to say it twice: literally 40% of steam players who beat chapter 1, missed out on the endings in chapter 2 (I looked up achievement rates). For me, each one of those four endings was enough to blow my mind and make this game one of my favorites... for all four of them to be so stunning is a testament to Hideo Kojima's skill as a director. Like remember the whole scarecrow bit from Batman: Arkham Asylum? That's the level of, 'WTF AM I SEEING???' that these endings brought... and many people missed out on them.

After finally beating the game 100% and playing Metal Gear Online for a few hours I feel like I should write a review for this game. It took me around 140 hours to reach 100% completion and this requires you to get S rank on all missions, complete all side-ops, collect all animals, and do all side objectives in every mission. If I didn't mess around in a lot of that time then I probably could have beaten it in 100-120 hours. When compared to other Metal Gear games this one seems to have the most replay value for its single player. The only other one which comes close for me is Peace Walker which I played for approximately 100 hours on the PS3.  The gameplay in Metal Gear Solid 5 is different enough from past Metal Gear games to feel fresh. It's more of a sandbox than previous games as you're given many different ways to complete your objectives. They all boil down to a stealthy approach or guns blazing in the end but they give you many toys to play with. Once you reach the end of the game you're likely going to have a large amount of weapons. Especially if you develop your FOBs and take advantage of the online development projects(displayed as gold boxes).  FOBs are your Forward Operating Bases. Each one of them allows you to add 100 staff members to each of your squads for a grand total of 700 staff members per FOB. If you want the best weapons in the game then you need to have a few FOBs. The only downside to having FOBs is that you might get invaded and lose some of your staff members(lock the important ones so you don't lose them). It most likely won't happen or at least won't happen often as long as you don't have any nukes or participate in the security challenge. If you are going to build a nuke for the achievement then make sure to do this offline so you can dismantle the nuke immediately and get the other achievement.  Now to talk about the story. This is probably Metal Gear Solid V's weakest point. The story isn't terrible but it feels incomplete. I'm not going to go into too much detail about that but you're left with many questions and the ending is completely anti-climactic. It was so anti-climactic that many people thought that there was more to the game and went on a wild goose chase to find the 'true ending'. Unfortunately, it's not like Peace Walker and there is no secret ending. What you see is what you get. It's not the perfect bridge between Big Boss's story and Solid Snake's story but I think it's the best we can hope for at this point.  After beating the game you might do what I did and try to get 100% completion. This is much more difficult to do than I thought it would be. Not because the missions are geniunely difficult but because of bugs I didn't notice the first time around. Once you start aiming for the optional objectives then you'll probably run into the same bugs that I did. Prisoners not spawning in, conversations never beginning, and other small issues which will eventually grind down your patience with the game. Some characters need to follow a very strict path and if anything interrupts them then you will either miss a conversation or the conversation will end early. This could be anything from your dog running into them or getting too close to the area where an interrogation is supposed to take place which somehow makes the interrogation target trip on the door frame. The second glitch I mentioned can be solved by keeping at least 60 meters away from the last interrogation room in Lingua Franca until the target is in the middle of the room and the interrogation is about to start.  The side-ops are pretty fun at first but then they start feeling repetitive. It might be fun to eliminate the heavy infantry the first few times but after the 10th time you'll likely feel like it's a hassle. The same goes with the other mission types. In the end I found myself just going in to the elimination side-ops guns blazing to get them done as fast as possible. Of course, I only felt like this after the first 100 hours or so. I can't really say that the side-ops were terrible but they weren't as fun as the ones from Peace Walker and they were definitely not that rewarding. Especially since it's not co-op and you're not playing with other people.  The animal collection is probably the only thing I really hated about the game. The rest is either disappointing or mildly annoying. Not only does it not make sense to gather all of the different animals but other than a couple of them(especially the Jehuty) there was no real reward to get them. Just some GMP, heroism, and an emblem piece. If there wasn't an achievement then I probably wouldn't have done it. This is different from the music which has no achievement but I collected willingly because the music itself was a reward. As a side note, I have had Too Shy stuck in my head for the last few hours.  As for the graphics, there's not much to say there. The graphics are pretty good and the game played pretty smoothly for my computer. There were only a few times when I noticed it dipping down but it didn't feel like it ever hit 30 FPS. As I've got an Intel i7 3770K and an Nvidia GTX 780 this wasn't really unexpected. I don't play with Motion Blur or Depth of Field but I had everything else maxed out in 1080p and locked my framerate to 60 in Rivatuner. Since I never looked at my FPS I can't really say much more.  I loved the soundtrack to MGSV since I like a lot of songs from the 80s but I feel like they should have had other Metal Gear songs included. This is easily solvable by adding the songs to the game yourself though so I can't really fault the game on this part. Just put your MP3s in the CustomSoundtrack folder found in the game's folder.  All in all I'd say that the game is worthy of getting an 8/10 if you consider a 5/10 to be average. I think that if they added in the Battle Gear, allowed co-op gameplay in the story, fixed the conversation bugs, and completed the story then it'd definitely deserve a perfect score.  Metal Gear Online is pretty fun but I'm kind of bad at it. I mostly played MGSV by taking advantage of the AI using distractions so I'll have to get used to going up against other people. In the meantime, I apologize to any team members that I end up dragging down with me. Also, it'd be nice if there were people that played more than one game type.

Unfinished, disappointing story, good gameplay. Not recommended for MGS fans.       Edit: I'll elaborate a bit:            (Spoilers ahoy)           Remember the whole 'The missing link that will solve the biggest mystery in MGS history!'?  Yeah that went well.  The story has an unbelievable amount of plot holes, straight up unfinished character arcs, a reliance on one rather convenient plot device to explain pretty much anything out of the ordinary (*cough* worse than nanomachines *cough*) and generally ends up being unsatisfying considering the inherent lack of any real boss fights (except the 1 Metal Gear), a weak main villain, the most unfitting use of the main theme since I can remember in any video game in the past decade, an over-reliance on recycled missions that make up more than 70% of the content, coupled with almost MMO-like side-ops that act as filler to the main game. Venom Snake barely speaks at all, which actually acts to the detriment of the game, as he just ends up staring cluelessly and awkwardly in most cutscenes, much like I did after I finished the game. 2/3 of the game has been cut out, and that is not an exaggeration. The third chapter is not even in the game, and the second one just screams 'we couldn't finish this, sorry' as it is filled with 80% recycled missions from the first chapter and 20% 'new' missions that make you visit the same places. In fact, the trailers for the game have MORE cutscenes than the actual game. The trailers actually use pretty much every semi-important cutscene in the game that isn't 'Snake goes to Mother Base to take a shower' and they even feature some cutscenes that were not featured in the actual game at all. The game also features these 'moral choices' because apparently this is fashionable in 2015, but it falls flat considering you get a whopping 1 (one) 'moral' choice and one illusionary choice that has the same outcome regardless of what you pick.  The gameplay, while probably the closest the MGS series has come to 'true stealth', isn't without its' faults. The 'open world' is really just 2 medium-sized maps that are mostly barren, barring the occasional goat and guard outpost. You get to visit these guard outposts/bases about 10 times or more, which makes them almost insufferable in the late game, when most of the game just revolves around you re-visiting places you've already been to numerous times. There is no 'find a steam friend' function to the online invasion system, so abandon all hopes of playing with a friend. Much like Ground Zeroes, where it had the very tedious trials to artificially inflate gametime, this game has side-ops, extra objectives and animal rescuing, among others. While not inherently flawed as an idea, the side-ops are just dumb, with amazing missions such as 'Mine Clearing 15', 'Eliminate the Armored Vehicle Unit 20', 'Rescue the Prisoner 14', the extra objectives work wonders when paired with the bad lua scripts that make obtaining some of them straight up hell (I'm looking at you, 'listen to the full conversation between x and y') and apparently I was wrong to think that I could collect animals by finding them in the actual game and catching them. No, that would make too much sense. You find SOME animals that way, sure, but it's only about 30-40%. To get the rest (which you could have found and captured in MGS3 , mind you) , you have to place a capture cage on the ground and hope the RNG gods give you a rare animal when you extract. Great. Mother Base is mostly empty, you only really go there to see the occasional cutscene and maybe practice for online invading. The AI is also dumb. Really dumb. The 'I just accidentally ran over a fellow guard with my truck, I should alert HQ that we have an intruder' kind of dumb.  There are many other points and flaws I could analyze endlessly, but the general conclusion is the same.  I'm not sure whether it's because Kojima and Konami had a falling out or if Kojima just lost his writing ability ever since MGS4, but this is the weakest Metal Gear game in terms of story.  'But, you don't have to enjoy the story! You can just play the game!' I hear people cry. Sure, why would anyone enjoy the story in a game series that is famous for the length of its' cutscenes and its' story?  Be that as it may, the satisfaction of playing as Big Boss, the legendary mercenary, really goes down when you you find out that you're actually just 'some guy' who is in pretty much every sense of the word 'Big Boss' except that the story dictates that he's not just to shove a weak plot twist down your throat and to make some dumb point about the title of 'Big Boss'.

I grew increasingly frustrated with Metal Gear Solid V. It started out with potential, but the litany of things grew. I didn't like the inability to jump and would find this exceedingly aggrevating when trying to escape a firefight. But the glitchy slides up rock faces and the almost jerky movement would further my dislike of Snake. The psychotically long runs between places didn't add to the realism, so much as make for some very boring running. And Snake sounds like he runs with the horses, he's so noisy.  Also, trying to figure out how to assign your team to do missions behind the scenes was an exercise in futility. I never managed to have one successful outing. What about side missions - no, not the actual side missions, but the ones that allow 100% completion of a mission? Well you don't even get to know what they are until you complete the mission one full time, meaning you have to do every mission at least twice if you want to complete everything. And actual side missions? You can complete one a dozen times and somehow it keeps coming back!  Lastly, speaking of running too far... what about your base. Even using a helicopter to 'fast travel' seems to be a display of how it really would be circling repeatedly over a base... again and again until landing.  Overall, I've played many first and third person games and have finished all of them. This is the first time I feel I grossly wasted money - I uninstalled it after mission 11. I kept trying to go back to it, to complete it, but found it too tedious. There are better games out there and I've spent my money far better on Steam in the past. This was a major let down.  Sadly, I far exceeded my time on it so can't get a refund. Here's to never making that mistake again!

Even if the game had been completed, even if Kojima and Konami had the jolliest of cooperation during development, MGSV will still be a major disappointment. Even as it's own game, it's pretty mediocre..  As someone who has 20 hours into Ground Zeroes, I was pumped for MGSV; and, as someone with 20 hours in GZ, I can safely say Camp Omega was the best level in all of MGSV... by far. The levels are so basic and boring, barely any of them being unique or complexly assembled (like Camp Omega). Even the good levels become a bore ought to how many times you'll need to infiltrate them. This game has a horrible progression system, and that's not even to hide the cut content. MGSV is so horribly placed. You'll play for hours and not progress in the story or unlock more gameplay features. Was it fun? Yes, on and off, for about the first 10 to 20 hours. After that, no, it just become the same thing over and over. Maybe if the game had stuck to the 'realistic' tone Kojima had been going for, it all wouldn't have been so monotonous. The reason we aren't using rations and carrying 20 different weapons at all times is to supposedly make the game grounded in reality. It was like that in Ground Zeroes, and for the first 2 hours of TPP. After 10 hours, the player will be abducting tanks will giant balloons while fending off soldiers with Snake's rocket propelled prosthetic arm.  A lot of people like to praise that there's so much to do in this game. Well, that content becomes stretched really thin with this much padding. Plus, once you discover the most efficient way of sneaking past (suppressed sniper rifle and running up to anything and hitting LMB) there's no incentive to play the game differently. The slow progression and constant reuse of levels (even in Chapter 1. Side ops require infiltrating the same settlements over and over) make the game a chore at times.  This may all be forgiven if TPP could provide a wonderful narrative to connect the series, and somehow reframe events. Take MGS3 for example. It provided new insight into the characters we had interacted with in MGS1, 2, and even the game, Metal Gear. MGSV adds nothing, absolutely nothing. In fact, it uses the previous games as a crutch for its character development, if it just doesn't just disregard how these characters acted in previous games (looking at you Ocelot). So many scenes in this game don't make any sense, because, at the last moment, the game remembered that this character needs to be alive or something for the next game. Every character is completely one note, with absolutely no twists. Big Boss is a mute. Kaz is angry. Ocelot is a rational encyclopedia. Eli's a brat. Skull Face only cares about revenge. Heck, the only character that has any semblance of character development is the underwear glad Quiet, and she still is a walking contradiction. Is she a licentious gal that just wants to sleep with Big Boss? Is she a brutal, cold, violent murderer that we should be on edge over? Who cares! Show more of her butt to the camera. Even the big twist at the end (which requires a bunch of grinding too unlock, yippee) is full of plotholes and contradictions, creating more questions (and facepalms) than answers. Maybe this is why the game has quotes that tell the player to choose their own canon.  Edit: For some reason, people think this is an amazing PC port. It isn't. The game is capped to 60fps, features no mouse support in the menus, has horrible multi-core support, runs significantly worse on AMD GPUs, features a lot of low-res assets, tons of pop-in, mediocre K&M controls, and has several graphical settings tied to the same changeable setting in-game. The only reason it's praised it because he will almost always run at 60fps when using console settings, which should be the case since it almost always ran at 60fps on the consoles. It's not an amazing port. It's okay, serviceable, but there is a lot to improve

This game is a bit of a mess. An incomplete story which moves slow as hell at the start but then shoves some incoherent ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at you towards the end. People claim that Act 1 was good but it honestly just seems that way due to how hilariously bad Act 2 is, Act 1 suffers from amazing pacing problems as well and ends really abruptly.  The open world thing is really mismanaged as well, it basically means that there are dozens of mostly identical outposts that you can run between with nothing of note in the glorified corridors between them. I miss the carefully crafted environments from earlier MGS games. The open world only adds padding since it takes so damn long to go anywhere and it takes ages for your the quick travel helicopter to actually move somewhere.  All the missions ends up blending together after a while, take out X, exfiltrate Y. After a few hours you've done pretty much every thing that you will do in the game. Tons of padding missions where you are going after some generic dude that maybe kinda sorta is connected to the main plot. The boss fights are extremely uninspired or not there at all ( the earlier games had amazing last fights but here you get to fight    a generic tank squad? Really?    ).  Harry Gregson-Williams isn't doing the music (only gets a producer credit) in this game and it's unfortunately really obvious, the soundtrack is servicable and all but it's just so damn bland which definitely isn't something you could say about the soundtrack in earlier games.  The actual stealth gameplay is pretty decent but I really don't get how this got 10/10 from so many reviewers. I have zero urge to replay this game after finishing unlike every other main Metal Gear game which I felt that I wanted to play again the moment I finished it.  Then you get into how Kojima and Konami promised that this would cover the gap between the Big Boss games and the Solid Snake ones, but we do not get that at all except for a minute-long epilogue. And why is Ocelot such a boring character who only exists to exposition dump when he has so much personality in all the other games he's in, both before and after this one?  Man, I just wanted another Snake Eater :(

Great gameplay marred by forced online component  This is the first MGS game I've played, and it's also sadly going to be my last.  The game itself is *excellent* -- tactical espionage action in a near open world, with almost complete freedom in how to accomplish your objective, whether you go loud and kill everyone in your path, or sneak through and leave nothing behind but a few tumbleweeds where valuable materiel was supposed to be.   If only Konami hadn't made the utterly stupid call to make the online FOB component entirely non-optional.  I can see how people might like it, I can even see how it'd be interesting to try -- but the fact that I don't get the option of declining to have a nontrivial chunk of my resources and personnel vulnerable to being stolen by a random griefer permanently sours me on it. The fact that you're expected to spend real world money for 'MB coins' to build those resources up further is just adding insult to injury.   If this is the direction Konami's taking its games in, I'm going to head the other way.

The gameplay is nothing short of excellent. The visuals are superb, and optimized greatly for all types of hardware. It is the next true evolution in the Metal Gear Solid franchise in terms of gameplay and tactical stealth (or guns blazing if you're that boring). Every new mission that is started is another tale to be told because nothing ever, EVER goes the same way twice. The AI is some of the best I have ever encountered in a video game, while bending to some levels of absurdity just so certain gameplay devices can work. Audio is also masterfully done, even though there's a total lack of options in-game.   But I have to not recommend this game to any longtime Metal Gear fan, who will obviously be expecting heavy heaps of story, just not as much as MGS4. This game has two wrong things with it. Two very big wrong things. Not only is it actually an unfinished game - with the latter half composing almost entirely of filler missions - but the quality Metal Gear cutscenes and story we've come to expect were either cut entirely out or moved to cassette tapes. There are some cutscenes that are incredible, no joking, but there is a definite lack of them. You will acquire a huge amount of story cassette tapes over the course of the game, when they could have just served as cutscenes instead. Indeed, Keifer Sutherland does a good job as Venom Snake, but fails to deliver any lines where they would really be needed, and by that I mean he is a silent protagonist for more than half the game. The main story also takes a nosedive into nothing once the first chapter is completed. There are only three main missions in chapter 2 that actually progress the story. The rest are harder versions of chapter 1 missions. Then you get the final mission and it's just over.  This game was truly made for non-hardcore fans of the series, in terms of gameplay and structure. Perhaps story as well, because gameplay is just absolutely everywhere, you cannot complain. I would recommend this game if that were the only case, but in reality, the game is incomplete. Chapter 1 ends like it was the end of the entire game. It should have probably stayed that way, with how Chapter 2 stretches itself out and ends.  I actually do recommend this game if it's on sale and you're a noob to the Metal Gear series. It's a load of fun and perfects the 'fun' parts, but also removes what series veterans have come to expect from this franchise. This game is the most playable in the entire series, but even Ground Zeroes had a better story than this, and that game could be played normally at two hours.

Want to love this game but the FOB Missions are some next level EA ♥♥♥♥ery.   Long story short: Your Forward Operating Base is what allows you to expand your base, get people, and thereby progress through the game a bit easier. You get unlocks and upgrades through this system as well as a host of other gameplay features. The entire single-player game revolves around Mother Base, your FOBs, and your army.   Problem is that other players can invade your FOB and steal your people. They can do this even while you are offline. You are practically forced to participate because many of the unlocks and upgrades require a certain Security Team level, which only comes from having an FOB. So, if you want to enjoy the single-player, you have to subject yourself to other players taking your building resources and people.   There is an 'offline mode' but all this does is delay the inevitable, as you will immediate receive the effects of any player invading your FOB (taking your people/resources) the next time you log in. Which, by the way, you have to do in order to upgrade your FOB in the first place, and if you don't you hamstring your own progression.   TL;DR - FOBs are an online mode that you must use to get the full experience but doing so impacts your single player experience in a pretty significant way.   For that reason, I do not recommend this game until they get it fixed. No game, especially one stemming from a primarily Single Player franchise, should ever be impacted by other players when you are not able to contribute to your own defense.

I didn't rike it.  A lot of people decry Konami for ruining this game, but it's clear to me that while Konami maliciously shut this game down because Kojima slept with somebody's wife or took a ♥♥♥♥ on the floor, it was Kojima himself that ruined MGSV.  I've been a huge Metal Gear fan for a long time, but playing this game was like watching someone ten meters from the finish line of a marathon slip on a banana peel, spill coffee all over himself, trip over a railing, fall down a flight of stairs, then get hit by a subway train.  First of all, the gameplay mechanics are incredible. It feels like Kojima took the best elements from every stealth game and sewed them into a beautiful tapestry. The controls are silky smooth and very responsive. The gameplay systems that complement the controls, like the stealth, enemy interaction, and unique features such as reflex mode, are very well designed. Kojima really knocked it out of the park with the core gameplay, but the content that puts that gameplay to use is where he stumbled.  MGSV is so unnecessarily repetitive. All of the small towns/enemy bases spread across the game's two maps are exceptionally well designed, but the game's insistence on making you return to those same locations several times each is what dulls the experience.  There are 157 side missions in the game, and they all kind of blur into one by the end. One series of side missions is called 'Extract the Highly-Skilled Soldier', where you have to sneak into an enemy base or outpost and extract a specially-marked enemy back to your Mother Base. The problem is that there are 16 'Extract the Highly-Skilled Soldier' missions that have you infiltrate bases and outposts you've already infiltrated countless times. What's worse, is that there's another series of side missions called 'Prisoner Extraction' that has you infiltrate bases and outposts you've already been to, where you need to... find a specially-marked prisoner and extract them back to your Mother Base. There are 20 of these missions. Even a different side mission series like 'Eliminate the Armored Vehicle Unit' will pit you against a collection of armored vehicles and enemy soldiers, and you will inevitably extract all of them back to Mother Base, because, well, that's how the game wants you to play.  MGSV gives you so much freedom to approach any scenario how you want, but at the same time, the game is also designed to encourage you to play one very specific and limiting way. In order to have a thriving Mother Base, you need skilled soldiers which predominantly can only be acquired by extracting them back to your base during a mission. So even though the game allows you to take a very brash, lethal approach, you end up feeling forced to play a completely different way. I would have loved to play through the whole game as stealthily as possible, slipping through the enemy ranks without giving them any indication I was there at all, but instead I approached every base and outpost the same way: mark every enemy from a distance; tranq them or sneak up and choke them one by one; then extract them back to my base until the guard post is empty. The restrictive nature of this gameplay becomes very tiring, and it was only after I had completed the large majority of the game and had my Mother Base R&D team develop every weapon and item I thought I might need to complete the rest of the game, that I was able to open up my gameplay style and start killing or ignoring guards if I wanted to.  Somewhere along the way Kojima decided to shift from a linear, simplified experience where you sneak through one long mission comprised of unique and interesting areas that are punctuated with entertaining story cutscenes, and go more toward a disjointed and stat-heavy game. Many times, it didn't feel like I was playing an MGS game so much as managing finances in accounting software. Rather than trying to create a fun and memorable game, it seems like Kojima (and/or Konami's influence, perhaps) tried to make the game as addictive as possible. There were many times playing the game where I felt like I was having fun, but I realized that what I found 'fun' was spotting an S-ranked soldier with my binoculars. This made me understand that I wasn't having fun at all, but that instead, spotting this S-rank fired off the OCD triggers in my brain that are at the core of every addictive behavior. It's experiences like this that sour my opinion of the current state of the game industry. Imagine how much better it would have been to sneak through an entire game made up of unique areas as well designed as the mission from Ground Zeroes, without all the useless stats.  The Mother Base system is a shining example of everything that's wrong with MGSV. You spend all of your time grinding by extracting soldiers back to your base and building it up. But for what? You can assign the soldiers you acquire to different units at your base, like Combat, Research & Development, Intel, Medical, etc., and each unit has different responsibilities that they carry out. But when you take a step back and look at all of it, most of it does nothing useful. The Combat team can be sent out on automatic missions that happen in the background and return with materials. The Medical team will patch up any Combat team soldiers that were wounded on their missions so they can go on more missions and acquire more materials. So what are materials used for? Well, you use them to build additions to your Mother Base so that you can have more soldiers per unit, which in turn will increase the level of each unit and allow them to acquire even more materials so you can... ??? Hopefully you're understanding the useless cycle that this creates. In fact, the only unit at your base that matters at all is the R&D unit which is responsible for developing every weapon and piece of equipment that you can use in the game. Rather than the good old procure-on-site method of collecting weapons in previous MGS games, this game requires you to painstakingly knock out and extract every enemy in sight, regardless of how you want to play, so that you can go through the whole Mother Base rigamarole to upgrade your R&D unit so they can develop the weapons/items you want/need.  The story was a real letdown too. A lot of people complain that Konami caused the final mission to be cut from the game, but even if you watch the unfinished version of that mission on YouTube, it still doesn't add a satisfying conclusion. The game literally has no ending. You know it's over because it stops giving you missions. There wasn't even a final boss fight. There was a particular plot/character I thought this game was going to revolve around, but it didn't really even touch on it. It doesn't feel like a bridge between MGS3 and Metal Gear; it just feels like a meandering side story. Many semi-interesting plot threads fizzle out with no explanation. Characters like Ocelot don't even seem related to themselves from other games. The last time Snake and Ocelot saw each other, they were in a fistfight on a plane, and at the start of this game, Ocelot shows up with no explanation and is apparently Snake's best buddy. Character actions and motivations feel vague and fluid in this game, and answers to questions only provide confusion and plot holes.  MGSV had the potential to be the coolest game ever made. The gameplay mechanics, systems and level design are all top notch. The graphics are fantastic and the cutscene direction and camera work are the best I've ever seen in a game. Just slick as hell. Unfortunately, the frustrating repetition, lack of meaningful game and story content, and the mind-numbing stat management all bring this game down. If Kojima had patterned this game a little more like MGS3, it might have truly been something special. If you want the most satisfying MGSV experience, just save your money and watch the E3 2015 trailer and imagine what could have been.

Chapter 2 gives you about twice the story in about a quarter of the time, and then abrubtly ends, leaving huge gaps in the plot. Some of these holes could have been filled by the cut 51st mission, which the only way to 'experience' it is to watch the video included with the collector's edition. Even then, I guess we're just supposed to make assumptions about what happens from now until Metal Gear 1 on the MSX2.  Within the first 10 missions you'll realize what's really going on here. Most of the time, you'll be running around either a desert or a jungle looking for a specific person to kill, attach a balloon to, or carry away. Kojima said that we would be able to play the missions in any order, and the story would still make sense. Unfortunately, the way that they accomplished this was by making most of the 'story' missions not actually impact the story at all, whatsoever. Not only that, but of the 50 main missions in the game, 12 of them are just hard mode repeats of old missions.  Chapter 1 is 31 missions. Chapter 2 is 7 missions. What is even the point of having a second chapter?  People have datamined a titlecard for the 3rd chapter, but we would have found it by now. Mission 51 wouldn't be cut if there was more.   We play Metal Gear for a great single player experience, but MGSV's single player was rushed and gutted in order to make room for the online multiplayer elements. Clash of Clans style base building, complete with pay-to-win micro-transactions for extra base-building space and base insurance, not to mention the recent costume DLC. And mind you, PC players don't even get Metal Gear Online (the main multiplayer portion of the game) until January, despite the fact that console players have had it for about half a month now.  The longer you get into this game, the more you realize how awful it really is. As the missions get unbearably unfair (A Quiet Exit being the worst offender, the only story mission I haven't beaten), and the plot degrades into a series of anecdotal one-offs that lead nowhere, you become cynical enough that it doesn't matter that Keifer Sutherland is yelling 'ROCKET PUNCH!' and using balloons to send animals into the sky.  The game might as well be a dream (which is actually a theory some people have) because everything that happens is eventually revealed to be either a complete fabrication, a hallucination, or just entirely inconsequential to the series as a whole.  That said, this is by far the best open world game ever made. Everything you do affects your base, your soldiers, your private army's morale, resources, and global influence.  Unfortunately, it's the worst Metal Gear game ever made, and because of that, I absolutely cannot recommend it.

So I recently finished the story for the game. And I have been a big fan of the MGS series ever since the first one for PS1. I have not played the first two MG games for NES or the psp games, but I have seen the story via videos on the net.  The good points are as following:  + Gameplay is pretty solid, pun intended :P The CQC is greatly improved, the gun combat and the movement is also greatly improved over previous games. So this is where the game truly shines is on gameplay and that is the core gameplay. All the gear and assets you can use are mostly great, especially the buddy system and there are lots of ways to play and do missions.  + The graphics are stellar and on PC it is very well optimized. To have it look this well and run at 60fps all the time is really great for a multi platform game.   The Middle Ground  +/- + Story presentation. When the story is presented to you through cutscenes it is some of the best directed cutscenes you will ever see in a game. They are beautifully made and very engaging. The bad part of the story presentation is that there are way to few cutscenes that tells the story, most of the story is told through cassette tapes and it gets so tiresome listening to all of them. I wish some of the important stuff had been presented through some sort of cutscene or at least in a better way than through tapes. Why not something similar to the codec moments in previous games, not a fix, but at least it would have been better.  The bad  - The story itself is to me very lackluster and very sparse. Which is to me a huge minus for this series. I have always loved the stories in these games and the amount of cutscenes have never been an issue for me. It seems they traded gameplay for story and that is just not good for a MGS game. It feels unfinished, the ending comes out of nowhere, and I hear there is even a whole chapter that has been cut out of the game.  - Big Boss as a character.... is boring... He has no character, he barely speaks and I have no idea why on earth they had to change the voice actor as the facial motion capture is most of the time not noticeable, since he almost never speaks. Most of his dialogue is once again through boring tapes. Jack Bauers delivery is not bad, it is just and unnecessary change, I have no doubts that David Hayter could have done just as good a job on the facial motion capture.   - To many silent characters. Big Boss, enemy bosses, Quiet (though she should be quiet), Eli has so few lines or never even says anything, making their characters boring and just not that important really. They are just there, they don't add much to the story.  - Chapter 2 is poorly designed, with most of the missions just being the same missions from chapter 1, just with new challenges added to them. The story missions has to be unlocked by doing certain stupid criterias. The ending comes out of nowhere and has no build up. It feels like a whole chunk of the game is missing.  - Mother Base is annoying as hell and mostly pointless. There is not much to do there besides the silly MP mode, some cutscenes plays out and there are a few collectibles and secrets. But to have such a detailed part of the game be pretty much useless is just stupid. You have to upgrade it by pretty much grinding resources and fulton staff from the open world to upgrade and unlock new weapons. And you have to even wait for 30+ minutes to unlock items, which is really annoying when you are going on a mission and just wanted to unlock a new tool for that mission.  - Lack of some stealth mechanics that are sorely missed. Why can't I shoot the radios anymore, that was so handy in the previous games, and shooting someone in the leg or the hand does nothing, while even in MGS that made them either unable to use their weapon or walk slowly and actually get handicapped.  So to end this review I have to both recommend and not recommend it, unfortunally I can't do a middle ground on this game on a steam review so I will go with a not recommended rating. There are just way to many negatives for me to hartly recommend it, especially for other MGS fans. But for people who don't even care about the story, then I do recommend it because of the rock solid core gameplay which will keep you entertained for a long time. But this game feels unfinished and just lacking that which all the previous MGS games has had and that is the epic and satisfying cinematic story.

Gameplay is fine, story is not. Mostly Spoilefree review, I'll warn you.  As a huge metal gear fan, i am disappointed about the story. It touches dark subject matter then immediately turns 180 degrees. Where is the 'Taboo', the dark elements of the game that was promised in the trailers, interviews and et cetera. Most of the storyline are told through cassette tapes, which couldve been amazing cutscenes. When does 'Snake' become a 'demon'?  One of the missions, was very emotionally powerful. You get the sense that Venom Snake is going on his downward spiral to demonhood, but he never does. He's just a characterless, morally 'good guy' throughout the whole game. Hideo Kojima, the game director, even told that he wanted to make a dark character, but someone we could feel bad for, and understand, - like Walter White from Breaking Bad.   The only thing i really loved about this game was the intro, really, really well executed. Voiceacting was also superb.  Several of the themes are never fully realized. There was much potencial with child soliders, but it never went anywhere after the missions were done. The story is way too sparse to the point where all the events feel disconnected from one another. The game is litterally unfinished, most of the missions were somewhat irrelevant, just extract this, or do something else.   The only characters that got a conclusion is the main antagonist, 'Skullface', and Quiet, which is optional. The main characters don't really do anything, they are just at motherbase doing nothing. I don't really care about sexualization of the character 'Quiet', but at least write her better than this. She's boring, and really unnecessary. Skullface is also rushed, had potencial.  The biggest ♥♥♥♥ you to the fans was the 'secret ending'. It doesn't make sense. It feels like It's just a twist, for the sake of being a twist.   Spoilers: The twist was that you're the Medic from GZ. In MGS4, Big Boss tells Old Snake; 'you eliminated me 2 times before'. What the ♥♥♥♥. And the thirst of revenge on Big Boss, because he left him to make a better and heaven by his own vision? What the ♥♥♥♥. There was so much potencial, the cutscenes and dialogue was mostly beautiful. Skullface could've been the real big boss for example, or just an poetic symbol of someone he is becoming. The game could've ended in the shoes of Solid Snake, killing off Big Boss because of his madness - recreating the original Metal Gear.   In conclusion: ♥♥♥♥ this game. It's an unfinished mess, that deserves less praise than it gets.

The game itself is a lot of fun - but there's one design decision that critically cripples this game.   The single player campaign is tied to the online servers, because a lot of your inventory is stored online (for some purpose that I have not been able to figure out.) If those servers go offline (as they seem to do at least once a week), that inventory becomes unavailable. Now, I could even live with that, but, a lot of your CASH is also tied up online, and, if the server goes offline, that cash becomes unavailable -- which means you start suffering negative effects from being in the red, even if you have plenty stuck online on a server somewhere.  That design decision means that it doesn't matter how good you are at base management - if the servers go offline, you're done. At best, you're at a point where you can turn off the game and not play it until the online servers are back up, so you suffer minimal ill effects. At worst, your base suffers, people leave, you can't buy that support you need to finish a mission, etc.   Tying a single player game to online servers in such a way that their availability cripples your ability to play the single player game is such a bad decision, and it's enough for me to swing me to no on this game, even though the game itself has been fun so far.

tl;dr: Metal Gear Solid 5: The Phantom Cash Grabber, The Phantom Permission Slip, The Wait Wall Extortionist.  Everything in the game has a Wait Wall (ranging from less than a minute to 8+ days) asking you for money to sell you Permission to unlock (now rather than up to 8+ days later) recycled content you already paid for. The F2P/MMO cancer infests every Grade 3+ Weapon and Item, every Mother Base Platform, every Forward Operating Base platform, every Combat Deployment, in Single Player and Multi-player.   When you pay Konami to shut off a Wait Wall, you are not paying Konami to do any work. You are paying Konami for PERMISSION for your computer to shut off the Wait Wall, to use the content you already paid for. It's Wait Wall Extortion.  The missions and side ops are treadmills for grinding the resources to feed the wait wall that will extort money from you so you can have permission to unlock your content now instead of upto 8+ days from now, even in Single Player.  MGSV:TPP is an F2P/MMO cancer infesting an interactive comic book. It's like a Single Player game with toll booths that let you wait it out or pay for the Permission to move along.  MGSV:TPP has added an online connection to Single Player, which is as useful for Single Player as a third hand growing out of one's posterior. The Single Player does with the online connection and F2P/MMO cancer (wait walls, virtual currency [Mother Base Coins], treadmills, and farming) the same thing that any other Single Player game has done better for the past 30+ years without any of that F2P/MMO pollution getting in the way of Single Player.  The story is interesting. Various game mechanics are fun. The graphics and audio are great. But, the game play and story are ruined by the parasitic F2P cancer that Konami has forced onto the game.  I consider this game a throw away experience best avoided because it tries to get you to spend your life on it's treadmill, paying to unlock what you already paid $60 for, even in Single Player.

Metal Gear Broken 3 is finally out, and I can finally review this game as whole. Let's do it (at this point, it sounds like those review videos on YouTube, hehe):  Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain: PROS: The game is gorgeous, it looks good, it plays good, gameplay mechanics are awesome, a lot of gadgets to experiment with. Combining multiple gadgets will let you see how enemy soldiers react, you can change the color of your cardboard box, and you can even put a poster of a hot female or marine onto it, it will trigger enemy soldiers, there you can come behind them, kill them, strangle them, whatever you want. When you get an enemy, you can kill him, stunt him, or ask him for additional info, like where other enemies are, etc. You have multiple buddies, each customizable in many ways. A lot of outfits, for each of them, customizing chopper, it's weapons, customizing Quiet (a buddy you meet in one of the missions), her costumes and weapons, there is a cute dog, which colors and suits could be also changed. And much more. You can do some side ops, meeting with soldiers that can let you customize your weapons colors/skins, all of these features make the game awesome. The way rain falls on character suit making it wet and graphics that makes all this look beautiful is amazing. Gameplay as said earlier is perfect. Movement options, you can walk really slow, take cover, everything is done with a lot of details, it's amazing. The thing I enjoyed the most on the other hand, is music. Oh God, so many beautiful melodies, brings this game to the TOP. Just staying in the desert, listening to games original theme from your iDroid gives me chills.  CONS: Oh boy. This part literally destroys the majority of sweet things game offers. I'll start with the story, as it's the most important thing of this game of course. I never played previous MGS, and this is my first one. My 'start'. And I liked it... Most of the time. But way the main protagonist just keeps mouth shout is irritating. Somebody asks him a question, he replies with just YES or NO, it's not like it isn't enough, but I'd expect a little bit more, I'd expect something deeper, to better connect me with character. As I said, it's my start, so when I saw [spoileri]Ellie flying away with those kids and that machine[/spoileri] I felt like I'm on the half of the game... But it was the end. The mission that should have occurred later was removed due to it being incomplete. I was kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but what I played until that, was just AMAZING. Game has a lot of unlogical things that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off, sometimes you'd be noticed trough walls, but at the end of the day, it's single-player, nobody cares mate, you'd just go on, you can install save games at any time, you can reply at enemy time, nobody cares... So, there were not any more CONS in single player except, Incomplete Story, Silent Protagonist, Unlogical 'things'.  METAL GEAR ONLINE 3: Kill me, please: PROS: So it's finally here, and things I'm going to complain about here, are the ones that will not be changed after BETA release, as it's like this on consoles for few months already, and it isn't fixed. But let's get to the few good things that are in here. First, you are in able to customize female characters, creator is decent, it lacks some features, like more hair maybe, but again, they are soldiers, and it's not so useful for them (and then again, quiet had ponytail, she was also soldier God damn it), Online has a new place, that isn't available in Single Player, and that's awesome. Graphics and gameplay are same as it is in Single Player and nothing new here. Those are pretty much only good features of MGO3, everything else is similar to other shooters. CONS: Oh boy, where do I start? First, the game has 5 maps, which are really huge, for 3 really small and boring game mode, of which one is so broken, nobody plays it. There is a RUSH feature, which makes these maps smaller, but then, they are so small. Good thing there is weather feature, you can set time, and it can really change the look of the map, they look insanely different at day and at night, which is cool I guess. A thing that literally strangles me is the suicide feature, the way character will die from same height on one edge of the map, and will survive from the other, makes me cringe. Another disgusting thing is that weapons randomly get nerfed, and it takes so long to get new weapons. The Same weapon deals less damage as you progress for some reason. It's one of those multiplayer games that has 9 thousand levels, each unlocking something useless, but every thousand levels you will get a gun or something that can hurt enemies. Then, you can have only 3 characters, but you can't customize them after you create them. It's one of the stupiddest things ever. And one character you must have is the one you create at the beginning of the game, you can not change his gender or anything like that, and back when I made him, I asked on forums, 'how do I make a female character', quoting a player from discussions who's name I can not remember ''If I'm going to look at ♥♥♥ for the majority of game time, it better be female at least.'', the guy had a point. Back to the topic, I said how nobody cares about unlogical stuff in single player, but multiplayer has logical issues, its just disgusting mate. Machine gun can deal more damage from distance then sniper can, what. And it's not the worst thing, cloak class has a lot of advantages, as at specific parts of the level they are completely invisible, it can cost you a whole match sometimes. Also, game does not have any anti-cheat feature and seems like it won't in the full release, making it a Heaven for cheaters. There is a lot more I can rant about here, but I just can't. CONS UPDATE 1: Every second spent in this ''game'' just reveals how bad it actually is. You will come across players who spam Rocket Launchers, 'cause they can. Seems like some developers never heard of balance. Also, grenades explode right after being thrown. Sweet. CONS UPDATE 2: As sh*ttiest online game I have ever played, RPG spam is a piece of cake, when you come across players who spam Grenade Launchers, as they have better rate of fire. But maybe I have misunderstood this game. It's an indie studio, game made by 10 people, other 20.000 have some type of brain disease as it seems.   Other issues with online are something that will hopefully be fixed in full release, such as better team balance, team and all chat, some minor issues with latency, and more costumes and stuff. For a sect of Kojima prayers around that go trough these reviews voting them off just because they don't recommend the game, please understand this: Game is awesome. Kojima did a great job with the story. But the studio left it unfinished. Kojima made singleplayer awesome, Online was left for Konami and Kojima Productions, and it's really bad. By how it is, it will not survive for too long. Stop praising everything without a little bit of criticism.', and again, for an incomplete story, paying 60 dollars is too much. It isn't any better if you get a broken multiplayer in that price. You read what I wrote, you decide. Good luck.
